questions.text: From which of the following does the inferior thyroid artery arise?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Thyrocervical Trunk

  • The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which is a branch of the subclavian artery. The thyrocervical trunk arises from the first part of the subclavian artery and gives rise to several branches, including the inferior thyroid artery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - External carotid artery: The external carotid artery gives rise to the superior thyroid artery, which supplies the superior portion of the thyroid gland. However, it does not give rise to the inferior thyroid artery. 

Option B - Internal carotid artery: The internal carotid artery primarily supplies the brain with oxygenated blood and does not directly give rise to branches supplying the thyroid gland.

Option D - Lingual artery: The lingual artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, supplies blood to the tongue and oral cavity structures but not the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Broca’s Area

  • Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere, controls speech production by coordinating motor movements. Damage to this area can cause Broca's aphasia or expressive aphasia, characterized by difficulty forming words and producing fluent speech. While speech is impaired, comprehension usually remains intact.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wernicke's area: Damage to Wernicke's area results in receptive aphasia or Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by impaired language comprehension and fluent but nonsensical speech.

Option C - Heschl's area: Heschl's area, the primary auditory cortex in the superior temporal gyrus, processes auditory information. Damage here isn't likely to cause the described symptoms.

Option D - Striate area: The striate area is involved in visual processing and is not directly associated with language production or comprehension.

questions.text: Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of thumb after supracondylar fracture is due to the involvement of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D.

Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb after a supracondylar fracture is due to anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) involvement. AIN, a branch of the median nerve in the forearm, innervates deep flexor muscles, including the flexor pollicis longus responsible for thumb flexion. With a supracondylar humerus fracture, AIN compression or injury can weaken or paralyze the flexor pollicis longus, causing thumb joint flexion inability.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Deep branch of ulnar nerve: The deep branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the hypothenar eminence and intrinsic hand muscles, not thumb interphalangeal joint flexion.

Option B. Median nerve: Median nerve injury typically leads to a broader pattern of motor and sensory deficits in the hand.

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve: The posterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the radial nerve, mainly innervates extensor muscles in the forearm and doesn't play a direct role in thumb flexion.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Proprioception

  • Proprioception, which refers to the sense of body position and movement, is not primarily processed by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Proprioceptive information from the face and head is primarily conveyed through other sensory pathways, such as the proprioceptive fibers within cranial nerves like the facial nerve (CN VII) and glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Temperature: Temperature sensations from the face and head are transmitted through the trigeminal nerve and processed in the spinal nucleus.

Option B - Pain: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve processes pain sensations from the face and head.

Option C - Touch: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve also processes touch sensations from the face and head. It receives sensory input related to light touch, pressure, and tactile sensations.

questions.text: Which artery does not provide blood supply to the corresponding area of the dura mater among the following options?

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery – anterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal branch of maxillary artery – middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery – posterior cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery – anterior cranial fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery – posterior cranial fossa:

  • Meningeal branch of the internal carotid artery – posterior cranial fossa: The internal carotid artery primarily supplies the brain with blood, but it does not directly supply the dura mater in the posterior cranial fossa. Instead, the posterior cranial fossa's dura mater is mainly supplied by branches of the vertebral arteries, including the posterior meningeal arteries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Middle meningeal artery – anterior cranial fossa: The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery and supplies the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, including the frontal and parietal regions.

Option B - Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery – middle cranial fossa: The accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery supplies the dura mater in the middle cranial fossa, which includes the temporal and sphenoid regions.

Option D - Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery – anterior cranial fossa: The meningeal branches of the anterior and posterior ethmoid arteries supply the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, specifically the ethmoid and frontal regions.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent nerves does not participate in the sense of smell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypoglossal nerve

Explanation:

  • The sense of smell is primarily mediated by the olfactory nerve (CN I).
     
  • However, other cranial nerves can contribute to chemical sensation (like irritation or pungency) from substances inhaled through the nose:
     
    • Trigeminal nerve (CN V): Detects irritating or pungent stimuli (e.g., ammonia, menthol).
       
    • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): Provides sensory innervation to the nasopharynx and posterior tongue, indirectly contributing to flavor perception.
       
    • Vagus nerve (CN X): Has sensory fibers in the nasopharynx and larynx that detect chemical irritation.
       
  • The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) is a pure motor nerve that innervates the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue and has no sensory or olfactory role.
     

Nerve

Role in Smell/Chemical Sensation

Trigeminal nerve

Detects noxious/pungent chemical stimuli (e.g., ammonia)

Glossopharyngeal nerve

Sensory to posterior tongue; involved in taste/flavor

Vagus nerve

Sensory to nasopharynx/larynx; detects chemical irritation

Hypoglossal nerve

Motor to tongue; no sensory or olfactory function

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Dexamethasone:

  • In this scenario, the 18-year-old girl with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) developed fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates on a chest X-ray. These symptoms and findings suggest the development of a potentially serious complication called acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) associated with APL.
  • Dexamethasone, a corticosteroid, is the appropriate choice of drug in this situation.
  • It is commonly used in the management of APL to help mitigate the differentiation syndrome, also known as retinoic acid syndrome, which can occur during the initial treatment with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) or arsenic trioxide (ATO).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cytarabine: Cytarabine is a chemotherapy drug commonly used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), including certain subtypes of APL.

Option C - Doxorubicin: Doxorubicin is a chemotherapy drug commonly used in the treatment of various cancers, including APL.

Option D - Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug used in the treatment of various malignancies, including certain types of leukemia.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that passes through the foramen marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Oculomotor nerve

  • The image shows the superior orbital fissure, which is a bony opening located in the sphenoid bone of the skull. The oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III) passes through this fissure. The oculomotor nerve is responsible for controlling the movement of several eye muscles, including the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which elevates the upper eyelid.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Olfactory nerve (Cranial Nerve I): The olfactory nerve enters the skull through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone and is not associated with the superior orbital fissure..

Option C - Optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II): The optic nerve carries visual information from the eyes to the brain and enters the skull through the optic canal, not the superior orbital fissure.

Option D - Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII):The facial nerve controls facial muscles and exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen, not the superior orbital fissure.

questions.text: What is the primary function of the muscle indicated in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Elevation

  • The muscle in the image is the temporalis muscle, situated on the side of the head over the temporal bone.
  • The main action of the temporalis muscle is the elevation of the mandible (lower jaw). When the temporalis muscle contracts, it pulls the mandible upwards, closing the mouth and bringing the teeth together for biting and chewing. This action is essential for various oral functions, such as eating, speaking, and swallowing.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Depression: Depression of the mandible refers to the downward movement of the lower jaw. The temporalis muscle is not involved in this action.

Option C - Protrusion:Protrusion of the mandible is the forward movement of the lower jaw. Although the temporalis muscle can contribute, it's not the primary muscle responsible for this action..

Option D - Retraction: Retraction of the mandible refers to the backward movement of the lower jaw. The temporalis muscle does not play a significant role in this action.

questions.text: What is the cause of infertility in individuals with Kartagener's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Asthenospermia:

  • Kartagener's syndrome, also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), is a rare genetic disorder that affects the structure and function of cilia. Cilia are hair-like structures present on the surface of cells, including cells in the respiratory tract and reproductive organs. In Kartagener's syndrome, there is a defect in the structure and/or function of cilia, leading to various clinical manifestations, including respiratory problems and infertility.
  • In the context of infertility in Kartagener's syndrome, the most likely cause is asthenospermia, which refers to reduced or absent sperm motility. Cilia play a crucial role in sperm motility, as they provide the propulsive force needed for sperm movement within the female reproductive tract. In Kartagener's syndrome, the defective ciliary function can result in impaired sperm motility, leading to reduced fertility.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are not specific features of Kartagener's syndrome and are incorrect.

questions.text: Which muscle is not involved in the inversion of foot?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

  • Peroneus longus: The peroneus longus muscle, also known as fibularis longus, is located on the lateral side of the leg. It is primarily responsible for eversion (turning outward) of the foot, not inversion. Eversion is the opposite movement of inversion and involves turning the sole of the foot outward.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Tibialis anterior: The tibialis anterior muscle is located on the front (anterior) side of the leg. It is responsible for dorsiflexion (lifting) of the foot and inversion of the foot. It plays an important role in controlling the foot position during walking and running.

Option B. Tibialis posterior: The tibialis posterior muscle is located on the back (posterior) side of the leg. It is a powerful muscle that contributes to both inversion and plantar flexion (pointing) of the foot. It helps to maintain the arch of the foot and provides stability during walking and running.

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: The extensor hallucis longus muscle is located on the front (anterior) side of the leg. It is responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot and extension of the big toe. While it does not directly contribute to inversion of the foot, it plays a role in maintaining the foot's position during various movements.

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over a property dispute when the elder of the two complained of chest pain and collapsed and was later declared brought dead by the hospital. His family says he was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Takotsubo cardiomyopathy:

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome, is a condition characterized by sudden temporary weakening of the heart muscle. It is typically triggered by intense emotional or physical stress. The name "Takotsubo" refers to the shape of the affected left ventricle, which resembles a Japanese octopus trap.
  • In the given scenario, the sudden onset of chest pain and collapse in the elder brother during an argument over a property dispute suggests a possible emotional trigger, which is commonly associated with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It is important to note that emotional stressors, such as arguments or intense emotional experiences, can lead to the release of stress hormones that can have a direct impact on the heart, causing transient cardiac dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Infective cardiomyopathy: Infective cardiomyopathy refers to myocardial inflammation caused by an infection, such as viral or bacterial myocarditis. While infective cardiomyopathy can present with chest pain and sudden death, there is no mention of an infectious illness or symptoms suggestive of an infection in the given scenario.

Option C - Acute myocardial infarction: Acute myocardial infarction, commonly known as a heart attack, occurs when there is a sudden blockage of blood flow to the heart muscle, usually due to a clot in a coronary artery. While chest pain and sudden death can be associated with a heart attack, the absence of risk factors, such as atherosclerosis or a previous history of heart disease, and the presence of emotional stress as a triggering factor make acute myocardial infarction less likely in this case.

Option D - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic heart condition characterized by abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, leading to impaired heart function. While hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause sudden cardiac death, the absence of a family history of similar diseases makes it less likely in this scenario.

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in –
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Elastic cartilage

  • Elastic cartilage is a specialized type of cartilage found in structures such as the external ear, epiglottis, and eustachian tube. Unlike other types of cartilage, such as hyaline cartilage, elastic cartilage contains a significant amount of elastic fibers in addition to collagen. Type II collagen is the predominant collagen type found in elastic cartilage, providing structural support along with the elastic fibers.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bone: Type I collagen is the most abundant collagen type in bone tissue. It provides strength and support to the bone structure.

Option B - Ligament: Type I collagen is the primary collagen type found in ligaments, contributing to their tensile strength.

Option C - Aponeurosis: Similar to ligaments, aponeurosis predominantly consists of Type I collagen, which gives it its strength and resilience.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is commonly used for treating community-acquired pneumonia in the outpatient setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Azithromycin:

  • Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) refers to pneumonia that is acquired outside of healthcare facilities. In the outpatient setting, the most common pathogens causing CAP are typically atypical bacteria, such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Chlamydophila pneumoniae, as well as certain respiratory viruses. Azithromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is commonly used as an empiric treatment option for CAP in the outpatient setting.
  • Azithromycin has several advantages that make it suitable for outpatient management of CAP. It has excellent activity against atypical pathogens, including Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Chlamydophila pneumoniae. It also has a long half-life, allowing for once-daily dosing, which enhances patient compliance. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vancomycin: Vancomycin is an antibiotic primarily used for the treatment of Gram-positive bacterial infections, particularly those caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It is not typically used as an initial empiric treatment for community-acquired pneumonia in the outpatient setting.

Option B - Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotic commonly used for the treatment of various bacterial infections. While it may be used for the treatment of CAP in specific cases, such as when there is a concern for more resistant pathogens or in patients with specific risk factors, it is not the first-line treatment choice in most cases of outpatient CAP.

Option D - Streptomycin: Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that has activity against certain Gram-negative bacteria. However, it is not commonly used as a first-line treatment for community-acquired pneumonia, especially in the outpatient setting.

questions.text: Meissner corpuscles are present in:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Papillary dermis

  • Meissner corpuscles, also known as tactile corpuscles, are specialized sensory receptors involved in the perception of light touch and vibration. They are encapsulated nerve endings located within the dermis, specifically in the papillary dermis. The papillary dermis is the upper layer of the dermis, directly beneath the epidermis. It is characterized by its uneven surface due to the presence of dermal papillae.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis, the deeper layer, lacks Meissner corpuscles but houses sensory receptors like Pacinian corpuscles, crucial for detecting deep pressure and vibration.

Option C - Basal epidermis: The basal epidermis, or stratum basale primarily consists of basal cells responsible for renewal and attaching to the basement membrane. Meissner corpuscles aren't present in the epidermis.

Option D - Stratum lucidum:. The stratum lucidum is a thin, translucent layer of the epidermis that is typically found in thick skin areas, such as the palms and soles. It does not contain Meissner corpuscles.

questions.text: In adults, at which level does the spinal cord terminate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - L1-L2:

  • In adults, the spinal cord typically ends at the level of the first lumbar vertebra (L1) or the second lumbar vertebra (L2). This termination point is known as the conus medullaris. It's important to note that the spinal cord does not extend down to the end of the vertebral column. Instead, beyond the conus medullaris, the spinal cord tapers into a bundle of nerve roots called the cauda equina.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - L3-L4: This option is commonly seen as the termination level of the dural sac, which contains the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) surrounding the spinal cord and nerve roots.

Option C - T12-L1: The thoracic spinal cord extends down to approximately the level of T12, and the conus medullaris is located in the lumbar region rather than the thoracic region.

Option D - L2-L3: Similar to option a), this level is commonly associated with the termination of the dural sac, not the spinal cord itself.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with sudden onset difficulty in micturition and defaecation. There was no history of a cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cauda Equina Syndrome:

  • Cauda Equina Syndrome is a medical emergency characterized by the compression of the cauda equina nerve roots in the lower spinal canal.
  • Clinical features of cauda equina syndrome:
    • Difficulty with micturition
    • Loss of anal sphincter tone or fecal incontinence
    • Saddle anesthesia
    • Gait disturbance
    • Pain, numbness or weakness affecting one or both legs.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Pott's Spine: Pott's Spine, also known as spinal tuberculosis, typically presents with chronic back pain, deformity, and constitutional symptoms such as weight loss and fever.

Option B - Guillain-Barré Syndrome: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is an autoimmune condition characterized by ascending muscle weakness, usually starting in the legs and progressing upwards.

Option D - Multiple Sclerosis: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) presents with a wide range of neurological symptoms, including muscle weakness, sensory changes, and coordination problems.

questions.text: Cardiac output can be determined using the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Capnography:

  • Capnography is the measurement and monitoring of the concentration or partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the respiratory gases. While capnography provides valuable information about respiratory status and CO2 elimination, it does not directly measure cardiac output. Therefore, it is not a method for determining cardiac output.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thermal dilution technique:

  • The thermal dilution technique involves the injection of a cold or warm saline solution into a central vein, typically the pulmonary artery or right atrium.
  • By measuring the change in temperature over time at a distant site, such as the pulmonary artery or a peripheral artery, cardiac output can be calculated based on the principles of thermal dilution. This technique is commonly used in pulmonary artery catheterization.

Option C - Esophageal Doppler:

  • Esophageal Doppler is a minimally invasive technique that uses an ultrasound probe inserted into the esophagus to measure blood flow velocity in the descending thoracic aorta.
  • By measuring the blood flow velocity, the cross-sectional area of the aorta can be estimated, allowing for the calculation of stroke volume and subsequently cardiac output.

Option D - Echocardiography:

  • Echocardiography utilizes ultrasound waves to visualize the heart's structures and assess its function.
  • It provides a non-invasive and comprehensive evaluation of cardiac anatomy and hemodynamics.
  • Cardiac output can be indirectly calculated using echocardiography by measuring the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) diameter and velocity-time integral (VTI) of blood flow through the LVOT.

questions.text: Which mineral in excess causes alkali disease in livestock?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Selenium

  • Alkali disease, also known as blind staggers or blindness, is a condition that affects livestock, particularly cattle, and is caused by an excess of certain minerals in their diet. Selenium toxicity is known to be one of the causes of alkali disease in livestock.
  • Excessive selenium levels can lead to oxidative stress and damage to cells, particularly in the nervous system.
  • The symptoms of alkali disease include neurological abnormalities such as impaired vision, lack of coordination, tremors, and muscle weakness. In severe cases, blindness may occur. These symptoms are associated with the toxic effects of excess selenium on the nervous system.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Manganese: Manganese toxicity is not associated with alkali disease in livestock. Excess manganese intake can lead to manganese toxicity, which primarily affects the nervous system. However, it does not cause the specific condition known as alkali disease.

Option C - Molybdenum: Molybdenum toxicity is not directly associated with alkali disease in livestock. However, high levels of molybdenum in the diet can lead to a condition called molybdenosis, which primarily affects ruminant animals such as cattle. Molybdenosis can interfere with copper metabolism, leading to copper deficiency and associated health problems.

Option D - Iron: Iron toxicity is not related to alkali disease in livestock. While excessive iron intake can cause iron toxicity in animals, it does not result in the specific condition described as alkali disease.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Yogurt

  • Lactose intolerance is a condition characterized by the inability to digest lactose, a sugar found in dairy products caused due to deficiency of lactase responsible to breakdown lactose.
  • Yogurt is produced through the fermentation of milk by bacteria, typically Lactobacillus and Streptococcus species. During the fermentation process, these bacteria produce lactase, which helps break down lactose into simpler sugars. As a result, yogurt contains lower levels of lactose compared to other dairy products.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Condensed Milk: Condensed milk is milk from which water has been removed, resulting in a concentrated form. It contains a high concentration of lactose, and therefore, is likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance in individuals with lactase deficiency.

Option B - Skimmed Milk: Skimmed milk refers to milk from which the cream (high-fat portion) has been removed. While the fat content is reduced, lactose content remains relatively unchanged. Therefore, skimmed milk can still cause symptoms of lactose intolerance in individuals with lactase deficiency.

Option D - Ice Cream: Ice cream is a dairy product that typically contains high amounts of lactose. Therefore, ice cream is likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance in individuals with lactase deficiency.

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby’s sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except:

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency:

  • White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency: This statement is false. A white patch of hair is not associated with PKU. It is commonly seen in another genetic condition called piebaldism, which is characterized by patches of depigmented skin and hair due to the absence of melanocytes in those areas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme defect: This statement is true. PKU is caused by a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting the amino acid phenylalanine into tyrosine.

Option C - Phenylacetate positive in urine: This statement is true. In PKU, due to the accumulation of phenylalanine, it is metabolized through alternative pathways, leading to the production of phenylacetate. Phenylacetate is then excreted in the urine and can be detected through laboratory testing.

Option D - Mental retardation is present: This statement is true. If left untreated, PKU can lead to severe intellectual disability and developmental delays. The accumulation of phenylalanine in the body, especially during the early stages of brain development, can cause damage to the developing brain, resulting in cognitive impairments.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to measure HbA1C?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ion exchange chromatography

  • HbA1C, also known as glycated hemoglobin, is a form of hemoglobin that is used as a marker for long-term glucose control in individuals with diabetes.

  • Ion Exchange Chromatography is one of the most widely used methods for measuring HbA1C in clinical laboratories.

  • It works by separating hemoglobin fractions based on their charge differences, allowing differentiation between glycated and non-glycated hemoglobin.

  • High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) with ion-exchange resin is considered the gold standard for HbA1C measurement

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Isoelectric focusing: Isoelectric focusing is a technique used to separate molecules based on their isoelectric points (pI). It is commonly used in protein analysis.

Option B - Affinity chromatography: Affinity chromatography is a technique that utilizes specific interactions between a target molecule and a ligand immobilized on a solid support.

Option D - Electrophoresis: Electrophoresis is a general technique that involves the movement of charged particles in an electric field to separate molecules based on their size, charge, or other properties.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO2 = 50, HCO3 = 28. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation:

  • pH = 7.12: This value indicates acidemia.
  • pCO2 = 50: An elevated pCO2 indicates respiratory acidosis, as it suggests inadequate elimination of carbon dioxide by the lungs.
  • HCO3 = 28: The HCO3 level is within the normal range, suggesting metabolic compensation.
  • Based on these findings, the diagnosis is respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.
  • In respiratory acidosis, once the CO2 spikes, there is excess production of H+ ions leading to a fall in pH (acidosis). There is a compensatory increase in bicarbonate values to neutralize the values of hydrogen by the reabsorption from the kidney.  

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation: Metabolic acidosis is characterized by a low pH and low bicarbonate level. 

Option C - Respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and low pCO2. 

Option D - Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation: Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and high bicarbonate level.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia presents to the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Myxedema coma:

  • Myxedema coma is life threatening complication of hypothyroidism that is triggered by UTI, MI, Stroke, CHF, abuse of sedatives.
  • Patients with myxedema coma present with altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and signs of systemic decompensation. The symptoms of constipation, dry skin, and menorrhagia are also commonly associated with hypothyroidism.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Septic shock: Septic shock is a life-threatening condition caused by a severe infection leading to systemic inflammation and organ dysfunction.

Option B - Cardiogenic shock: Cardiogenic shock occurs when the heart's ability to pump blood is severely compromised, leading to inadequate tissue perfusion.

Option D - Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia, or low blood sugar, can cause altered mental status and hypotension.

questions.text: What is the probable reason for the quadriparesis developed by a 60-year-old patient after being treated with a significant amount of hypertonic fluids for 24 hours following a history of hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C. 

  • In the given scenario, the patient presented with hyponatremia and was treated with a large volume of hypertonic fluids over a short period of time. Following this treatment, the patient developed quadriparesis. These findings are suggestive of central pontine myelinolysis (Choice C).
  • Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM) is a condition characterized by the destruction of the myelin sheath in the central portion of the pons, which is a part of the brainstem. It is typically associated with rapid correction of hyponatremia, especially when the correction occurs too quickly. In this case, the hypertonic fluids caused a rapid increase in serum sodium levels, leading to osmotic changes in the brain and subsequent damage to the myelin sheath in the pons.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Brain infarct: Brain infarct (Choice A) refers to the obstruction of blood flow to a specific area of the brain, resulting in tissue damage. While hyponatremia can contribute to the development of cerebral edema and increase the risk of brain infarction, the rapid correction of hyponatremia in this case is more consistent with CPM.

Option B. Brainstem injury: Brainstem injury (Choice B) can result from trauma or other causes and can lead to a range of neurological symptoms. However, the rapid development of quadriparesis following the treatment with hypertonic fluids suggests a more specific diagnosis of CPM.

Option D. Rare cause of hypernatremia: Hypernatremia refers to an elevated serum sodium level. In this case, the patient presented with hyponatremia and received hypertonic fluids, so the development of hypernatremia is not likely to be the cause of the patient's condition. Therefore, Choice D is an incorrect option.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Phosphofructokinase 1:

  • During fasting, metabolic adaptations occur to maintain energy balance. A key adaptation is the decrease in phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) activity, a crucial enzyme in glycolysis.
  • Glycolysis breaks down glucose to produce ATP, with PFK-1 catalyzing a regulatory step converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.
  • This decrease in PFK-1 activity reduces glycolysis rate, conserving glucose for tissues like the brain while utilizing stored energy sources like glycogen and fatty acids.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hormone-sensitive lipase - During fasting, hormone-sensitive lipase breaks down stored fats into free fatty acids and glycerol, providing energy from triglycerides.

Option B - Glycogen phosphorylase - Glycogen phosphorylase increases activity during fasting to break down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, maintaining blood glucose levels.

Option C - Pyruvate carboxylase - Pyruvate carboxylase activity increases during fasting to support gluconeogenesis, the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources like amino acids and lactate, ensuring a steady glucose supply.

questions.text: Which of the following processes does not necessitate 5' capping?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - tRNA of alanine:

  • 5' capping is a post-transcriptional modification that involves the addition of a modified guanine nucleotide (7-methylguanosine) to the 5' end of RNA molecules. This modification is important for the stability, processing, and translation of the RNA molecule.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - U6 snRNA: U6 snRNA participates in splicing processes in eukaryotic cells. Its 5' capping ensures stability and proper function during splicing.

Option C - mRNA for Histone: Histone mRNA encodes proteins crucial for DNA packaging. 5' capping of histone mRNA ensures stability and efficient translation into histone proteins.

Option D -  siRNA: siRNA molecules are involved in gene silencing. Their 5' capping protects them from degradation and aids in their incorporation into the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC) for target gene suppression.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Complementation:

  • In the given image showing the schematic of a blue-white assay used in screening recombinant vectors for inserted DNA fragments, the correct choice would be "Complementation"
  • The blue-white assay determines recombinant vector screening based on complementation, where an inserted DNA fragment restores the function of a disrupted lacZ gene.
  • This gene encodes β-galactosidase.
  • If the DNA fragment restores lacZ function, active β-galactosidase cleaves a colorless substrate (X-gal), resulting in blue colonies.
  • Complementation indicates successful restoration of lacZ function, observed as blue coloration in the assay.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Translation: Incorrect. Translation is the process of protein synthesis and is not directly related to the blue-white assay or screening recombinant vectors.

Option B - Transformation: Incorrect. Transformation is the introduction of foreign DNA into a host organism, but it does not specifically relate to the blue-white assay.

Option D - Conjugation: Incorrect. Conjugation involves genetic material transfer between bacteria through direct contact and is not directly related to the blue-white assay or screening recombinant vectors.

questions.text: A triad of asthma, systemic vasculitis and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Churg Strauss Syndrome:

  • Churg Strauss syndrome, also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), is a rare autoimmune condition characterized by a triad of symptoms including asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis 
  • Features of EPGA are:
    • Eosinophilic vasculitis that involves multiple organ systems
    • Asthma
    • Peripheral Eosinophilia
    • Neuropathy
    • Pulmonary infiltrates
    • Paranasal sinus abnormalities

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is incorrect regarding Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increased fibrinogen:

  • Increased fibrinogen is wrong about DIC (Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation).
  • DIC is characterized by activation of coagulation system
  • In DIC, fibrinogen levels decrease as it's consumed in clot formation, not increased, because it's used up in the excessive clotting process.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased schistocytes: In DIC, the presence of schistocytes is a characteristic finding due to the formation of microvascular clots and the subsequent shearing of red blood cells.

Option B - Increased PT:In DIC, there is activation of the coagulation system, leading to consumption of clotting factors. This consumption results in prolongation of PT, indicating impaired clotting function.

Option D - Increased FDPs: In DIC, there is increased activation of the fibrinolytic system, leading to increased levels of FDPs. Elevated levels of FDPs are often observed in DIC and can be used as a diagnostic marker.

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute kidney injury:

  • AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease) criteria are used to classify and diagnose acute kidney injury (AKI). These criteria provide a standardized approach for assessing the severity of AKI based on changes in serum creatinine levels, urine output, and the duration of kidney dysfunction.

Criteria

AKIN

RIFLE

Definition

Based on changes in serum creatinine and urine output.

Based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and GFR.

Serum Creatinine

Increase in serum creatinine ≥0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours or ≥1.5 times baseline within 7 days.

R (Risk): Increase in serum creatinine ≥1.5 times baseline or GFR decrease >25%.

I (Injury): Increase in serum creatinine ≥2 times baseline or GFR decrease >50%.

F (Failure): Increase in serum creatinine ≥3 times baseline or GFR decrease >75%.

Urine Output

Decreased urine output (<0.5 mL/kg/hour for >6 hours).

O (Loss): Persistent acute kidney injury with complete loss of kidney function for >4 weeks.

E (End-stage kidney disease): Persistent acute kidney injury with complete loss of kidney function for >3 months.

Staging

AKIN stage 1: Increase in serum creatinine ≥0.3 mg/dL or ≥1.5 times baseline or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6-12 hours.

AKIN stage 2: Increase in serum creatinine ≥2 times baseline or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hour for ≥12 hours.

AKIN stage 3: Increase in serum creatinine ≥3 times baseline or serum creatinine ≥4.0 mg/dL or initiation of renal replacement therapy (RRT) or urine output <0.3 mL/kg/hour for ≥24 hours or anuria for ≥12 hours.

RIFLE classifies severity based on the R, I, F, O, and E criteria.

Clinical Application

Used in research, clinical trials, and clinical practice for AKI diagnosis and staging.

Widely used in research, clinical trials, and clinical practice for AKI diagnosis, classification, and outcome assessment.

Limitations

Relies on serum creatinine and urine output, which can be influenced by factors such as age, muscle mass, fluid status, and medications.

Similar limitations as AKIN criteria.

More recent studies suggest that RIFLE may be more predictive of mortality and need for RRT.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chronic renal failure: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are specifically designed to classify acute kidney injury and are not applicable to chronic renal failure. 

Option C - Acute glomerulonephritis: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify acute glomerulonephritis. 

Option D - Nephrotic syndrome: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT appears normal. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Intravenous thrombolysis:

  • The presentation of left-sided facial paralysis and weakness in a patient with high blood pressure suggests a possible ischemic stroke involving the territory of the middle cerebral artery.
  • Thrmobloysis is the preferred treatment in this patient as there is no hemorrhagic stroke.
  • Window period for thrombolysis is <4.5 hours of symptoms onset.
  • Thrombolysis can be done up to 6 hours of symptom onset.

Option Options:

Option A - Nothing, since CT was normal: While the CT scan may not show any immediate abnormalities, it does not rule out an acute ischemic stroke.

Option B - Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel is commonly used for the prevention of recurrent strokes in patients with ischemic stroke of atherosclerotic origin.

Option D - Advice BP control: Blood pressure control is an essential aspect of managing acute ischemic stroke, but in this scenario, the immediate concern is the potential for thrombolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific marker for alcoholism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - GGT:

  • GGT is considered the most specific marker for alcoholism among the given options. GGT is particularly sensitive to alcohol consumption, and elevated levels of GGT are commonly seen in individuals who abuse alcohol or have alcohol use disorder. Monitoring GGT levels can be useful in assessing alcohol-related liver damage and evaluating the response to treatment for alcoholism.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ALT (Alanine aminotransferase): ALT is a liver enzyme that is often used as a marker of liver damage. While elevated ALT levels can be seen in alcohol-related liver disease, it is not as specific to alcoholism as GGT.

Options C & D (ALP & LDH) are not specific markers for alcohol consumption and are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea. D-xylose test was normal and the Schilling test was abnormal. A duodenal biopsy was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pancreatic insufficiency:

  • Pancreatic insufficiency refers to the inadequate production or secretion of pancreatic enzymes, including lipase, amylase, and proteases. This can lead to malabsorption of nutrients, particularly fats, resulting in chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea (excessive fat in the stool). In this case, the patient's symptoms of chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea suggest impaired fat digestion and absorption.
  • The D-xylose test is used to assess the absorption of xylose, a sugar, in the small intestine and an abnormal Schilling test result suggests impaired absorption of vitamin B12.
  • An abnormal Schilling test result suggests impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Celiac disease: Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition characterized by an abnormal immune response to gluten, leading to damage to the small intestine.

Option B - Ulcerative colitis: Ulcerative colitis is a form of inflammatory bowel disease primarily affecting the colon and rectum.

Option C - Intestinal lymphangiectasia: Intestinal lymphangiectasia is a condition characterized by dilated lymphatic vessels in the intestinal wall, leading to the leakage of lymphatic fluid into the intestinal lumen.

questions.text: A patient walks with a stomping gait. When asked to close his eyes and walk, he is unable to do so. Which of the following tracts is probably affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Posterior column tract:

  • A stomping gait, also known as a sensory ataxia, is typically due to loss of proprioception, which is the sense of the relative position of one's own body parts. Proprioception is mainly carried by the posterior column (dorsal column) of the spinal cord.
  • Function: The posterior column tract (or dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway) carries proprioceptive information, vibration sense, and fine touch.
  •  Damage to this tract results in loss of proprioception, causing a stomping gait as the patient relies on visual cues to know the position of their legs. When eyes are closed, the patient loses these cues, resulting in difficulty walking.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Spinocerebellar tract

  • Function: Carries unconscious proprioceptive information to the cerebellum to help coordinate movements.
  • Damage to this tract results in ataxia, but it is usually characterized by uncoordinated movements rather than a stomping gait. The patient might not show increased difficulty with eyes closed compared to eyes open.

Option C - Vestibulospinal tract

  • Function: Involved in maintaining balance and posture by controlling the muscles of the trunk and limbs.
  • Damage to this tract would result in balance issues, but the patient would not typically present with a stomping gait or show significant worsening with eyes closed.

Option D - Rubrospinal tract

  • Function: Involved in the fine control of limb movements, particularly the flexors.
  • Reasoning: Lesions in this tract are rare and typically do not cause a stomping gait or the described difficulty in walking with eyes closed. They might cause more subtle motor deficits.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease came with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. His blood gas reports show pH = 7.40, HC03- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, anion gap= 100 mEq/L. What is your probable diagnosis?

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis:

  • Normal pH of 7.40- Indicates no primary acid-base abnormality. However, the
  • Bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 23 mEq/L falls within the normal range- Suggests that there is a compensatory mechanism in place. 
  • Sodium (Na+) level of 145 mEq/L is also within the normal range.
  • Elevated anion gap of 100 mEq/L, which indicates the presence of an underlying metabolic acidosis.
  • High anion gap metabolic acidosis is commonly seen in conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and renal failure. In this case, the patient's chronic kidney disease is likely contributing to the development of high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Increased anion gap but HCO3 is not reciprocally reduced indicating presence of metabolic alkalosis component. 
  • The above findings suggests a diagnosis of High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No acid-base abnormality: This choice is incorrect because the blood gas reports indicate the presence of an abnormality, specifically a high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

Option B - Respiratory acidosis: The blood gas reports do not show any abnormalities in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2), which is a key indicator of respiratory acidosis. 

Option C - Metabolic alkalosis: This choice is incorrect because it only accounts for the metabolic alkalosis component of the patient's acid-base disturbance.

questions.text: Which condition necessitates the use of anti-nuclear antibodies for accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are autoantibodies that target components within the cell nucleus. They are important diagnostic markers for various autoimmune diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of a wide range of autoantibodies, including ANAs. ANA testing is a valuable tool in the diagnosis of SLE, as it helps to detect the presence of these antibodies in the patient's blood. The most common ANA pattern seen in SLE is a homogeneous (diffuse) pattern, although other patterns can also be observed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Scleroderma: ANAs are also present in scleroderma, another autoimmune disease, but their presence is not specific for scleroderma alone. Additional antibodies such as anti-centromere antibodies (ACA) and anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) antibodies are more specific for scleroderma diagnosis.

Option C. Drug-induced lupus: Drug-induced lupus is a condition that can occur as a result of certain medications, and it shares some clinical features with SLE. However, ANAs are not typically required for the diagnosis of drug-induced lupus. The presence of ANAs in drug-induced lupus is less common and usually of lower titer compared to SLE.

Option D. Sjogren's syndrome: ANAs are present in the majority of patients with Sjogren's syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth. However, the hallmark autoantibodies in Sjogren's syndrome are anti-SSA (Ro) and anti-SSB (La) antibodies. These antibodies are more specific for the diagnosis of Sjogren's syndrome than ANAs alone.

questions.text: In the sagittal section of the brain given below, if the coloured area is affected, which of the following is not seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Perianal anesthesia:

  • The sagittal section of the brain shown in the image likely represents a lesion in the area of the cerebral cortex known as the precentral gyrus or primary motor cortex. This region is responsible for motor control and coordination.
  • Perianal anesthesia: Perianal anesthesia refers to the loss of sensation around the anus. The precentral gyrus, which is primarily involved in motor function, is not directly responsible for sensory perception. Sensory information, including perianal sensation, is processed in the somatosensory cortex, which is located in the postcentral gyrus. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Urinary incontinence: The precentral gyrus is involved in the control of voluntary movement, including the coordination of the muscles involved in urinary continence. Damage to this area can disrupt the normal control of urinary function, leading to urinary incontinence.

Option B - Gait apraxia: The precentral gyrus is crucial for the initiation and coordination of voluntary movements, including walking. Therefore, damage to this area can result in gait apraxia.

Option D - Fecal incontinence: The precentral gyrus is involved in the coordination of the muscles involved in maintaining bowel continence. Damage to this area can disrupt the normal control of bowel function, leading to fecal incontinence.

questions.text: Which component of cement causes allergic dermatitis among construction workers in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Chromate:

  • The correct answer is Chromate. Chromate is a component of cement that can cause allergic dermatitis among construction workers in India.
  • Chromate is a known skin sensitizer, meaning it can cause an allergic reaction upon contact with the skin.
  • Construction workers who handle cement containing chromate can develop allergic dermatitis if they come into contact with the cement repeatedly over time.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Cobalt: While cobalt is used in cement as a drying agent, it is not primarily responsible for causing allergic dermatitis among construction workers.

Option B - Nickel: Nickel is not a component of cement and is not directly responsible for allergic dermatitis in this context.

Option C - Iron: Iron is an essential component of cement, but it is not known to cause allergic dermatitis.

questions.text: A patient came with fever, body ache, and joint pain. He was given NSAIDS. A few days later, he developed brownish pigmentation over the nose. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D

  • Chikungunya is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, particularly the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus species. The symptoms of Chikungunya typically include fever, body ache, and joint pain, which are similar to those described in the scenario.
  • One characteristic feature of Chikungunya is the development of brownish pigmentation over the nose, known as "Chikungunya pigmentation." This pigmentation is a specific dermatological manifestation associated with the infection and can occur during the acute or subacute phase of the disease. It is believed to be due to the deposition of hemosiderin, a pigment derived from the breakdown of red blood cells, in the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A Melasma: Melasma is a common skin condition characterized by brownish or grayish pigmentation on the face, particularly on the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. It is typically triggered by hormonal changes, such as during pregnancy or with the use of hormonal contraceptives. Melasma is not directly related to the symptoms described in the scenario or to the use of NSAIDs.

Option B Fixed drug eruption (FDE): Fixed drug eruption is a type of drug reaction characterized by the development of well-defined skin lesions after the administration of a particular medication. These lesions typically recur at the same site(s) each time the drug is taken. Brownish pigmentation may occur as part of the healing process, but the key feature of FDE is the recurrent appearance of the lesions at specific locations. The scenario does not mention any recurring skin lesions associated with drug intake, making FDE an unlikely diagnosis.

Option C Dengue: Dengue is another viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, particularly the Aedes mosquito. The symptoms of dengue include fever, body ache, and joint pain, which are similar to those described in the scenario. However, the development of brownish pigmentation over the nose is not a characteristic feature of dengue. Instead, dengue is known for causing other dermatological manifestations, such as a rash and red spots on the skin.

questions.text: What is the usual cause of a condition characterized by blistering and peeling of more than 30% of the body's surface area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • A disease associated with the occurrence of blistering and peeling of over >30% of the body surface area is usually caused by drugs. This condition is known as Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) or toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). SJS and TEN are severe skin reactions that can be life-threatening.
  • Both SJS and TEN are typically triggered by certain medications, most commonly antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). When a person has an adverse reaction to these medications, it can lead to widespread blistering and peeling of the skin, affecting more than 30% of the body surface area.

Incorrect Options:

Option A Viral infection: While certain viral infections can cause skin rashes and blistering, they are not typically associated with the extensive blistering and peeling of over >30% of the body surface area as seen in SJS or TEN. Viral infections that can cause skin rashes include herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus (chickenpox and shingles), and measles, among others.

Option C Fungal infection: Fungal infections generally do not cause the extensive blistering and peeling seen in SJS or TEN. Fungal infections of the skin, such as tinea infections (ringworm), typically present as red, scaly, and itchy patches on the skin, rather than blistering and peeling.

Option D Autoimmunity: Autoimmune conditions can result in various skin manifestations, but they are not specifically associated with the extensive blistering and peeling seen in SJS or TEN. Autoimmune blistering disorders, such as pemphigus and bullous pemphigoid, may cause blistering, but they do not typically lead to the widespread involvement of over >30% of the body surface area.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Isotretinoin:

  • When a patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face, the drug of choice for this condition is Isotretinoin.
  • This condition is known as severe or nodulocystic acne, and Isotretinoin is considered the most effective treatment option for this type of acne.
  • Isotretinoin is a retinoid medication that is derived from vitamin A. It works by reducing the size and activity of the sebaceous glands, which are responsible for producing excess oil that contributes to the development of acne. Isotretinoin also has anti-inflammatory properties, helping to reduce inflammation associated with nodulocystic acne

 

Incorrect Options:

 Option A - Steroids:

  • Steroids may be used in certain cases when there is a need to rapidly reduce inflammation, but they are not the preferred long-term treatment option.

Option C - Erythromycin:

  • Erythromycin is not the drug of choice for nodulocystic acne. Erythromycin is more commonly used as part of combination therapy

Option D - Tetracycline:

  • Tetracycline is not the drug of choice for nodulocystic acne.

questions.text: The histopathology picture below is suggestive of :
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pemphigus vulgaris:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the presence of intraepidermal blisters.
  • It is caused by autoantibodies targeting proteins involved in cell adhesion within the epidermis, leading to the detachment of cells (acantholysis) and the formation of blisters.
  • The blisters can rupture, leaving behind erosions. Histopathologically, pemphigus vulgaris shows suprabasal acantholysis, with the separation of keratinocytes above the basal layer of the epidermis as shown in the image.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Psoriasis vulgaris: Histopathologically, psoriasis shows epidermal hyperplasia (thickening of the epidermis), elongation of rete ridges, and a characteristic inflammatory infiltrate composed of lymphocytes.

Option B - Leishmaniasis:  Histopathological findings in cutaneous leishmaniasis include a granulomatous inflammatory response with intracellular amastigotes (parasitic form) within macrophages. It does not involve intraepidermal blistering like pemphigus vulgaris.

Option C - Mycosis fungoides: Histopathologically, mycosis fungoides show atypical lymphocytes infiltrating the epidermis (epidermotropism) and the presence of Pautrier microabscesses. Mycosis fungoides do not involve intraepidermal blistering like pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does the Gelles test yield a negative result?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Otosclerosis:

  • Gelles test, a vibrating tuning fork is applied over the mastoid process; if it is heard, the air in the external auditory canal is compressed, by means of a rubber tube inserted into the canal and a hand bulb, thereby fixing the stapes in the oval window,;aif the perception is not changed, the hearing loss is thought to be conductive; a test of the mobility of the ossicles.
  • In a normal ear, AC is better than BC, meaning that the person can hear sound through the air more efficiently than through bone conduction. This is indicated by a positive Gelles test, where AC is greater than BC.
  • . In otosclerosis, the abnormal bone growth can restrict the movement of the stapes, leading to a conductive hearing loss.
  • In otosclerosis, the Gelles test is negative. This means that BC is equal to or better than AC, indicating that bone conduction is as efficient as or better than air conduction. This is because the abnormal bone growth in otosclerosis can enhance bone conduction, resulting in a negative Gelles test.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - CSOM with Cholesteatoma. Cholesteatoma is an abnormal skin growth in the middle ear, which can lead to conductive hearing loss. However, it does not directly affect bone conduction. Therefore, the Gelles test would be positive or inconclusive, depending on the extent of the conductive hearing loss.

Option B - Senile deafness.Senile deafness, also known as presbycusis, refers to age-related hearing loss, typically involving sensorineural hearing loss. The Gelles test assesses bone conduction and should yield a positive result in cases of sensorineural hearing loss.

Option C - Meniere's disease. Ménière's disease involves episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and ear fullness. The Gelles test assesses bone conduction and should yield a positive result in cases of sensorineural hearing loss associated with Ménière's disease.

questions.text: A patient comes with an ulcer on the tongue with a duration of 3 months. On examination, there is a 3.5cm x 2.5 cm lesion with induration of 8mm. There was no lymphadenopathy. What is the stage of this lesion according to 8the AJCC guidelines ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • The staging of oral cavity cancers, including tongue cancer, is typically based on the guidelines provided by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC). The AJCC staging system takes into account various factors, including the size of the primary tumor (T), the presence of regional lymph node involvement (N), and the presence of distant metastasis (M).
  • In this scenario, the patient presents with an ulcer on the tongue that has been present for 3 months. The examination reveals a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm with an induration (hardening) of 8 mm. However, there is no lymphadenopathy (enlarged lymph nodes). Based on this information, we can determine the stage of the lesion.
  • According to the AJCC guidelines for oral cavity cancer, the T category is based on the size and extent of the primary tumor. In this case, the size of the lesion is 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm, which corresponds to a T3 tumor (greater than 4 cm in greatest dimension). The induration of 8 mm indicates invasion beyond the submucosa.
  • The N category, which assesses regional lymph node involvement, is determined by the absence or presence of lymphadenopathy. Since there is no lymphadenopathy reported in the scenario, the N category is N0 (no regional lymph node involvement).
  • Based on the T and N categories, the staging can be determined. According to the AJCC guidelines, the combination of a T3 tumor (size >4 cm with invasion beyond submucosa) and N0 (no regional lymph node involvement) corresponds to Stage II.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Stage I. Stage I is typically characterized by smaller tumors, usually less than 2 cm in greatest dimension, without evidence of invasion beyond the submucosa. In this scenario, the size of the lesion is larger than 2 cm, and there is evidence of invasion beyond the submucosa, making it inappropriate to classify it as Stage I.

Option C: Stage III. Stage III usually indicates larger tumors with extensive local invasion or regional lymph node involvement. In this scenario, there is no evidence of regional lymph node involvement, making Stage III an incorrect classification.

Option D: Stage IV. Stage IV typically indicates advanced disease with extensive local invasion, regional lymph node involvement, and/or distant metastasis. Since there is no lymphadenopathy reported and no mention of distant metastasis in the scenario, Stage IV is not the appropriate classification.

questions.text: A patient presents with oral cavity findings are seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient ?

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • In the given scenario, the patient presents with a wrinkled white patch on the ventral surface of the tongue, which is consistent with leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a potentially premalignant condition characterized by persistent white patches or plaques that cannot be wiped away and cannot be attributed to any other known cause.
  • Since the patient is a smoker, it increases the suspicion of the lesion being potentially malignant. Therefore, the next step in the management of this patient would be to immediately address the most significant risk factor, which is smoking. The patient should be advised to cease smoking as it plays a crucial role in the development and progression of oral cavity lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Giving corticosteroids: Corticosteroids may have some anti-inflammatory properties, but they are not the primary management option for leukoplakia. The use of corticosteroids in the absence of a definitive diagnosis and appropriate risk assessment is not recommended.

Option C. Lifestyle modification: While lifestyle modification is generally beneficial for overall health, it is not sufficient as the next step in the management of leukoplakia. The presence of a potentially premalignant lesion requires a more focused and immediate approach.

Option D. Injection vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause oral manifestations, but it is not the appropriate next step in managing leukoplakia. Vitamin B12 supplementation may be indicated if there is evidence of deficiency, but it does not address the underlying risk factors or provide a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the options below promotes the uptake of iron in the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Vitamin C

  • Vitamin C enhances iron absorption in the intestines. Iron exists in two forms: non-heme iron (found in plant-based foods) and heme iron (found in animal-based foods). Non-heme iron, which is the predominant form in most diets, is less easily absorbed by the body compared to heme iron.
  • Vitamin C acts as a reducing agent, converting ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which is more readily absorbed. Additionally, it forms a soluble complex with iron, protecting it from oxidation and improving its absorption in the intestines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vitamin A: Vitamin A is not directly involved in enhancing iron absorption. However, it is known to play a role in the regulation of iron metabolism and the storage of iron in the liver.

Option C - Thiamine: Thiamine, also known as vitamin B1, is not directly involved in enhancing iron absorption. Thiamine is primarily involved in energy metabolism and the functioning of the nervous system.

Option D - Riboflavin: Riboflavin, also known as vitamin B2, is not directly involved in enhancing iron absorption. Riboflavin is involved in various cellular processes, including energy metabolism and antioxidant defense.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent methods relies on RNA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - RT PCR:

  • RT-PCR is a technique that involves the reverse transcription of RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by PCR amplification of the cDNA. It is commonly used to study gene expression by quantifying RNA levels.
  • The process begins with the reverse transcription step, where the RNA template is converted into cDNA using the enzyme reverse transcriptase. The resulting cDNA is then amplified through PCR to obtain multiple copies of the target DNA sequence.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sanger's technique: Sanger sequencing, or chain termination sequencing, is a method for DNA sequencing that doesn't directly involve RNA.

Option C - Next-generation sequencing: NGS is a high-throughput DNA sequencing method used for various DNA-based applications, although it can also sequence RNA molecules.Although NGS can be used to study RNA by sequencing RNA molecules, the technique itself is not solely based on RNA.

Option D - Western blot: Western blotting detects and quantifies specific proteins in a sample, but it's not directly based on RNA, even though it can be used to analyze proteins encoded by RNA.

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a patient who experiences a sensation of room spinning upon standing up from lying down or turning his head, without any previous episodes of losing consciousness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo:

  • The symptoms described by the patient, feeling like the room is spinning when getting up from lying down or turning the head, are characteristic of vertigo. The most probable diagnosis for the patient's symptoms is BPPV. BPPV is a common vestibular disorder that occurs when calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) within the inner ear become dislodged and migrate into the semicircular canals. This can happen due to certain head movements, such as getting up from lying down or turning the head. When the dislodged otoconia stimulate the inner ear structures, it leads to a sudden and brief episode of vertigo.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Meniere's disease. Meniere's disease is a chronic condition characterized by recurring episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in the ears), and a feeling of fullness or pressure in the affected ear. Unlike BPPV, Meniere's disease is not triggered by specific head movements, and it typically involves additional symptoms beyond just vertigo.

Option C - Labyrinthitis. Labyrinthitis refers to the inflammation of the inner ear, typically caused by a viral or bacterial infection. It can lead to symptoms such as vertigo, hearing loss, and ear pain. However, in labyrinthitis, the vertigo is usually more persistent and lasts for several days or weeks, rather than being triggered by specific head movements as described by the patient. Option D - Syncope. Syncope refers to a temporary loss of consciousness and muscle tone caused by a transient decrease in blood flow to the brain. It is often triggered by factors such as low blood pressure, heart rhythm disturbances, or neurological conditions. The patient in this case does not have a history of loss of consciousness, which is a typical feature of syncope.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5’→3’ Exonuclease

  • Klenow fragment is a truncated form of DNA polymerase I that lacks the N-terminal region of the enzyme. It retains the DNA polymerase activity and the 3'→5' exonuclease activity, but it lacks the 5'→3' exonuclease activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 3'→5' Exonuclease: Klenow fragment retains the 3'→5' exonuclease activity. This activity allows the enzyme to proofread and remove mismatched nucleotides from the growing DNA chain during DNA synthesis.

Option C - 5'→3' DNA polymerase: Klenow fragment retains the 5'→3' DNA polymerase activity. This activity allows the enzyme to synthesize a new DNA strand using a DNA template.

Option D - 3'→5' DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase I, including its Klenow fragment, does not possess 3'→5' DNA polymerase activity. The DNA synthesis activity of DNA polymerases occurs exclusively in the 5'→3' direction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable outcome in a 12-year-old girl with poorly managed type 1 diabetes mellitus who is currently experiencing high blood sugar levels?

choices.text: Increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA

  • In inadequately treated type 1 diabetes mellitus, insulin deficiency impairs glucose uptake by cells, leading to increased lipolysis. Fatty acids are metabolized to acetyl-CoA through beta-oxidation, further entering the citric acid cycle for energy production.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - In hyperglycemic conditions like inadequately treated type 1 diabetes, muscle cells undergo glycogenolysis, breaking down glycogen to release glucose into the bloodstream, rather than glycogenesis.

Option B - Type 1 diabetes leads to protein catabolism, not increased protein synthesis. Insulin deficiency affects protein metabolism, causing breakdown for gluconeogenesis and energy.

Option D - Insulin deficiency in type 1 diabetes doesn't directly influence cholesterol synthesis. Cholesterol synthesis is regulated by other factors independent of insulin levels.

questions.text: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disc, is useful in identifying …………
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Streptococcus Pyogenes:

  • The test shown, which uses a bacitracin disc on a blood agar culture plate with a zone of inhibition around the disc, is useful in identifying Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • The test being referred to is the bacitracin susceptibility test. In this test, a disc containing a standardized concentration of bacitracin is placed on a blood agar culture plate that has been inoculated with the bacterial isolate. Streptococcus pyogenes is highly sensitive to bacitracin than other streptococci, showing wide range of inhibition as shown in the image.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test.

Option C - Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test.

Option D - Streptococcus agalactiae: Streptococcus agalactiae is resistant to bacitracin, so it would not show a zone of inhibition around the disc in this test.

questions.text: Which is the agent used to treat the infection caused by the cestode egg in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Praziquantel:

  • The given image is the Egg of Hymenolepis nana. The egg is round to slightly oval in shape. It has two membranes that surround an embryo with six hooklets. The space between the two membranes is filled by yolk granules. Both the poles of the embryophore are thickened.
  • The drug of choice to treat the infection is praziquantel works by causing severe spasms and paralysis of the tapeworm's muscles, leading to the detachment of the worm from the intestinal wall. It also increases the permeability of the tapeworm's cells to calcium ions, which ultimately results in the worm's death.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These drugs are not the drug of choice to treat infection caused by H. nana.

questions.text: A girl was allegedly kidnapped by a man. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the man, X ray images of her elbow, wrist and pelvis are given. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 21 to 22 years:

Explanation:

  • A method called skeletal age assessment can be used to determine an individual's approximate age based on X-ray images of their elbow, wrist, and pelvis. This method relies on assessing ossification centers and fusion of growth plates in these areas, which occur at predictable ages during development. The X-ray findings are consistent with the girl’s age of 21-22.

  • Findings:

    • Elbow: In a 21-22 year old female, the epiphyseal plates in the elbow region should be closed, indicating the completion of growth and fusion. The bones of the elbow joint, including the humerus, radius, and ulna, should appear fully developed and fused. The joint space should be minimal, and the bony contours should be well-defined.

    • Wrist: At this age, the growth plates in the wrist region should also be closed, indicating the completion of growth. The carpal bones of the wrist, including the scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, pisiform, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, and hamate, should be well-formed and have fused together. The bony architecture of the wrist should be well-defined.

    • Pelvis: In a 21-22 year old female, the pelvis should have completed its growth and reached its adult form. The ilium, ischium, and pubis bones of the pelvis should be fully developed and fused. The sacroiliac joints should be stable, and the symphysis pubis should be fused with minimal or no joint space.

Bone Region Epiphyseal Fusion Age (approximate)
Wrist (Lower end of radius & ulna) 17–18 years
Elbow (medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, capitulum, etc.) 14–16 years
Pelvis (iliac crest, ischial tuberosity) 18–21 years
Clavicle (medial end) 21–22 years (last to fuse)

questions.text: Identify the condenser in the following image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Below the stage:

  • In a compound microscope, the condenser is present below the stage in a compound microscope. It consists of an iris, which regulates the amount of light falling on the slide.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: What will be the gestational age of the fetus if the crown rump length is 21 cm and the length of the lower limb is 10 cm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • Crown Rump Length (CRL) is a standard measurement used to estimate gestational age during early pregnancy. It is the length from the top of the head (crown) to the bottom of the buttocks (rump) of the fetus. In this case, the CRL is 21 cm.
  • Generally, during the 6th to 7th month of pregnancy, the CRL of the fetus ranges from 20 to 24 cm. Since the given measurement falls within this range, the gestational age of the fetus can be estimated as 6 to 7 months.

Incorrect Options:
