Option B. 4 to 5 months: This option can be ruled out because the CRL measurement of 21 cm is larger than the typical CRL range for the 4th to 5th month, which is around 11 to 14 cm.

Option C. 7 to 8 months: This option can also be eliminated because the CRL measurement of 21 cm is smaller than the typical CRL range for the 7th to 8th month, which is around 26 to 30 cm.

Option D. Term: Term refers to the end of the pregnancy when the fetus is fully developed and ready for delivery, which usually occurs around 37 to 42 weeks of gestation. The given CRL measurement of 21 cm is smaller than what would be expected at term. At term, the CRL is typically around 35 to 38 cm.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			i. Heroin

			ii. MDMA

			iii. Joint

			iv. LSD
			
			
			
				
				Ganja
				
				
				Acid
				
				
				Brown sugar
				
				
				Amphetamine
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - i -3, ii-4, iii-1, iv-2:

  • Heroin: Heroin is a highly addictive opioid drug derived from morphine. It is commonly abused for its euphoric effects. Heroin is correctly paired with option 3.

  • MDMA: "Eve" is a term commonly used to refer to the drug MDMA, also known as Ecstasy. MDMA is a synthetic psychoactive drug with stimulant and hallucinogenic effects. Therefore, "Eve" is correctly paired with option 4.

  • Joint: A joint refers to a rolled cigarette containing cannabis (marijuana). Cannabis is commonly consumed for its psychoactive effects. Therefore, "Joint" is correctly paired with option 1.

  • LSD: LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) is a potent hallucinogenic drug known for its psychedelic effects. It can induce visual and auditory hallucinations. Therefore, LSD is correctly paired with option 2.

  • i. Heroin

    ii. MDMA

    iii. Joint

    iv. LSD

    3.Brown sugar

    4.Amphetamine

Incorrect Options:

Option A - i-2, ii-1, iii-4, iv-3: This choice incorrectly pairs Heroin with option 2, Eve with option 1, Joint with option 4, and LSD with option 3. The correct pairings have been explained earlier.

Option B - i-3, ii-2, iii-1, iv-4: This choice incorrectly pairs Heroin with option 3, Eve with option 2, Joint with option 1, and LSD with option 4. Again, the correct pairings have been provided above.

Option C - i-4, ii-2, iii-1, iv-3: This choice incorrectly pairs Heroin with option 4, Eve with option 2, Joint with option 1, and LSD with option 3. The correct pairings have been explained earlier.

questions.text: When an individual commences employment with a second employer, the new employer assumes responsibility for the individual's actions, under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Borrowed servant doctrine:

  • When a person starts working for a second employer, the new employer may assume responsibility for their actions under the Borrowed Servant Doctrine.
  • This doctrine applies when an employee is temporarily loaned or "borrowed" by another employer. In such cases, the borrowing employer assumes control over the borrowed employee and becomes responsible for their actions within the scope of their employment during the loaned period.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vicarious liability: Vicarious liability refers to a situation where one person or entity is held responsible for the actions of another person or entity.

Option B - Doctrine of negligent choice: The Doctrine of negligent choice refers to a legal principle that holds a party liable for choosing a negligent individual or entity to perform a task.

Option C - Contributory negligence: Contributory negligence assigns partial blame to a plaintiff for their own injuries or damages due to their failure to exercise reasonable care.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the given condition except:

choices.text: Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water
It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines
There are fewer chances of bacterial infection

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - There are fewer chances of bacterial infection:

  •  Human bites carry a high risk of polymicrobial infection by organisms such as Staphylococcus spp., Streptococcus spp., and Eikenella corrodens. Hence antibiotics are recommended.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water: It is recommended to moisten swabs with sterile water before sampling. Moistening the swabs helps in better collection of potential biological material, such as saliva or cells.

Option B - It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines: These teeth are more likely to leave identifiable patterns and impressions in a bite mark.

Option D - Tetanus vaccination should be given: This statement is true.

questions.text: If a healthcare professional is found guilty of professional misconduct, they must provide the patient's records promptly upon request, within:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 72 hours:

  • In cases of professional misconduct, when a patient requests their medical records, the healthcare provider is obligated to provide the records within a specific timeframe. The correct timeframe for providing patient records on demand in the case of professional misconduct is typically within 72 hours.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation for the correct answer.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene:

  • Ganciclovir is a nucleoside DNA polymerase inhibitor an antiviral drug commonly used for the treatment of CMV infections. Resistance to ganciclovir can occur due to mutations in the UL97 and UL54 gene of CMV.
  • Ganciclovir is converted by viral phosphotransferase encoded by the CMV UL97 gene to form ganciclovir triphosphate that inhibits CMV DNA polymerase. Mutations in the UL97 gene can result in reduced phosphorylation of ganciclovir, leading to decreased efficacy of the drug and the development of resistance.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell: Human fibroblasts are the most specific and ideal cell lines for the isolation of the cytomegalovirus.

Option C - The commonest manifestation of CMV-associated disease is watery diarrhea: CMV is the most common infection associated with congenital defects. In Immunocompetent individuals, after transplantation, it causes mononucleosis-like disease, and in immunocompromised individuals (HIV/transplantation), it causes, most commonly, CMV retinitis. 

Option D - UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross-resistance to Foscarnet: UL54 refers to the DNA polymerase gene of CMV, which is the target of antiviral drugs like ganciclovir and foscarnet, and mutation in this gene can lead to resistance against ganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir.

questions.text: Which organization is related to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Child and welfare committees:

  • Child and welfare committees play an important role under POCSO act, cases registered under this act need to be reported to CWC within 24 hours of recording of the complaint.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation for the correct answer.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization makes use of ………………
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hydrogen peroxide:

  • Plasma sterilization is a low-temperature sterilization technique that utilizes the fourth state of matter.
  • It uses plasma, plasma refers to a gaseous state consisting of ions, photons, free electrons, and free radicals (such as O and OH).
  • The plasma is generated by exposing the chemical hydrogen peroxide to radiofrequency waves.
  • The plasma can penetrate small crevices and cavities, making it an effective sterilization method for complex and delicate instruments like arthroscopes and ureteroscopes.
  • Control is Bacillus stearothermophilus.
  • Sterrad is a machine used for plasma sterilization.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ethylene oxide: It is a colorless liquid that disinfects by alkylating the amino, carboxy, hydroxyl, and sulfhydryl groups in protein molecules. It is highly inflammable, highly irritant, and highly explosive and is not used in plasma sterilization.

Option B - Gamma rays: Gamma rays are ionizing radiations that causes ionization of the molecules in organisms leading to breakage of DNA.

Option D - Ultraviolet radiation: It is a nonionizing radiation that causes the destruction of nucleic acid through the induction of thymine dimers. Used for surface sterilization of air, water, and surfaces.

questions.text: Bullet fingerprinting involve:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Both:

  • Bullet fingerprinting is a technique used in forensic investigations to analyze the unique markings left on bullets or cartridge cases by the firearm used to discharge them. 

  • Primary markings include the lands and grooves on the inside of the barrel, which leave distinct striations on the bullet or cartridge case as it passes through the barrel. These primary markings are the key elements that make each firearm's tool marks unique.

  • Secondary markings, may be present on a bullet or cartridge case due to factors such as the firing mechanism, extractor, or ejector of the firearm. 

  • When analyzing a bullet or cartridge case, forensic experts examine both the primary and secondary markings to compare them with test-fired bullets or cartridge cases from suspect firearms

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primary markings: Primary markings alone do not encompass the complete analysis involved in bullet fingerprinting.

Option B - Secondary markings: Secondary markings alone are also not sufficient for bullet fingerprinting analysis.

Option D - None: None is incorrect because bullet fingerprinting does involve the examination of both primary and secondary markings.

questions.text: Which of the following organism is represented by the given form of replication ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Influenza Virus:

  • The correct choice for the given form of replication is the Influenza virus.
  • Influenza virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Its replication process involves several distinct steps:
    • Attachment: The spikes of hemagglutinin bind to sialic acid found on the surface of the host cell’s membrane.
    • Entry: The virus enters the host cell by endocytosis, which involves the engulfment of the virus particle by the cell membrane and the formation of a vesicle called an endosome.
    • Fusion: The viral envelope fuses with the endosomal membrane, and the M2 ion channel allows entry of H+ ions - H+ influx, resulting in uncoating and releasing the viral genetic material into the host cell's cytoplasm.
    • Replication: The viral RNA serves as a template for the synthesis of new viral RNA segments (turning negative sense RNA into positive sense RNA), as well as viral proteins. The viral RNA polymerase, which is carried by the virus, is responsible for replicating and transcribing the viral RNA.
    • Assembly: Newly synthesized viral RNA segments and proteins are assembled into new virus particles within the host cell.
    • Budding: The assembled virus particles bud from the host cell's plasma membrane, acquiring an envelope derived from the host cell membrane. This process allows the virus to be released by neuraminidase and potentially infect other cells.

Incorrect Options: 

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the cause of death in smoke inhalation ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anemic hypoxia:

  • Smoke inhalation can lead to anemic hypoxia as the cause of death. Anemic hypoxia occurs when there is a reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. In the case of smoke inhalation, the inhaled smoke can contain toxic substances such as carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen cyanide (HCN). These substances can interfere with the normal binding of oxygen to hemoglobin in red blood cells, resulting in reduced oxygen transport throughout the body.

  • Carbon monoxide (CO) is particularly problematic as it has a strong affinity for hemoglobin and forms carboxyhemoglobin, which prevents the binding of oxygen. Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) interferes with cellular respiration and inhibits the utilization of oxygen by cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Histotoxic hypoxia: Histotoxic hypoxia refers to the inability of the body tissues to effectively use oxygen, even when an adequate amount of oxygen is available. It typically occurs due to the impairment of cellular metabolism or function, such as in cases of certain drug overdoses. Histotoxic hypoxia is not the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation.

Option B - Ischemic hypoxia: Ischemic hypoxia is caused by a reduced blood supply to tissues, resulting in insufficient oxygen delivery. It can occur due to conditions like cardiac arrest or severe blood loss. While smoke inhalation can lead to tissue damage and potential ischemia in specific cases, it is not the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation.

Option D - All of the above: This option is incorrect because all the given options are not correct.

questions.text: What is the appropriate course of action following the observation of cigarette burn marks on the forearm of a 14-year-old girl who presents to a doctor with a fractured forearm, claiming to have fallen and hit her hand?

choices.text: To do a complete physical examination
To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse
To call local social worker for help

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - To do a complete physical examination:

  •  When a 14-year-old girl presents with a fractured forearm and reports that she fell and hit her hand, it is essential for the doctor to conduct a thorough physical examination to assess the extent of the injury and evaluate any associated findings.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - To inform higher authorities: While it is important to address suspicions of abuse Before involving higher authorities, it is crucial to gather more information through a comprehensive examination.

Option C - To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse: Discussing the case with colleagues can provide additional insights, but it is necessary to gather more information through a comprehensive examination before making any definitive conclusions.

Option D - To call a local social worker for help: To call a local social worker for help: In cases where abuse is suspected,it is crucial to gather more information through a thorough physical examination and, if needed, reporting to higher authorities before contacting a social worker

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Strongyloides Stercoralis:

  • The image represents the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis. Points for identification.
  • Females are capable of asexual reproduction (Parthenogenesis)
  • Ovoviviparous larva comes out immediately from the egg
  • Infective form: Filariform larva penetrates the intact skin of the definitive host.
  • Route: By penetration of the Skin/autoinfection
  • Rhabditiform larva comes first and transforms into filariform larva in 3 ways:
    • Autoinfection: Penetrate intestine, produce Filariform larva
    • Direct cycle: Rhabditiform larvae exit the body and transform into Filariform larvae, and re-enters the body.
    • Indirect cycle
      • Rhabditiform larva forms adult(male and female), lays eggs
      • Eggs develop into Rhabditiform larvae
      • Rhabditiform larva transforms into Filariform larva

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ancylostoma Duodenale: Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that infects humans by penetrating the skin and migrating to the intestines. Its life cycle does not involve autoinfection.

Option C - Ascaris Lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides is a large roundworm that infects humans. Its life cycle does not involve autoinfection.

Option D - Enterobius Vermicularis: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, is a small nematode that commonly infects humans. Its life cycle involves the ingestion of eggs, hatching of larvae in the intestines, and migration to the colon and rectum for maturation and reproduction.

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Staphylococcus Aureus:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause food poisoning when contaminated food, particularly carbohydrate and protein-rich food, milk, meat, and fish, is consumed.
  • Staphylococcus aureus can produce heat-stable enterotoxins that can withstand 100°C for 10 to 40 minutes and cause rapid-onset symptoms of nausea and vomiting, typically occurring within a few hours (within 6 hours is characteristic) of ingesting contaminated food.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Salmonella typhi: Salmonella typhi is the bacterium responsible for causing typhoid fever. It is transmitted through the ingestion of contaminated food or water. However, the incubation period for typhoid fever is usually much longer, ranging from 7 to 14 days.

Option B - Vibrio cholerae: Vibrio cholerae is the bacterium that causes cholera, a severe diarrheal disease. Cholera is typically associated with the ingestion of contaminated water or food, usually in settings with poor sanitation. The incubation period for cholera is less than 24 hours to 5 days.

Option C - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery, a form of severe diarrhea. The incubation period for amoebic dysentery is typically longer, ranging from 2 weeks to 4 weeks.

questions.text: A patient has complaints of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert’s stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toluidine and Malachite Green:

  • Albert's stain is used for staining the volutin granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the bacterium responsible for diphtheria.
  • The constituents of Albert's stain are as follows:
    • Albert solution 1:
      • Green: Malachite green
      • Purple: Toluidine Blue- shows metachromasia.
    • Albert solution 2: Has iodine
    • First add Toluidine blue then Iodine and lastly Malachite green
    • On Albert's staining: organism-blue color and volutin granules-purple color.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. These are not the constituents of Albert stain.

questions.text: If a patient's plasma contains elevated levels of interferon beta, it is indicative of a probable infection caused by...
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Virus:

  • Interferon beta is a type of interferon that is produced by cells in response to viral infections. Interferons are proteins that play a crucial role in the body's immune response against viral infections. They help to inhibit viral replication, activate immune cells, and enhance the overall antiviral defense mechanisms.
  • The elevated levels of interferon beta in the patient's plasma suggest that the patient is experiencing a viral infection.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Interferon beta shows antiviral activity.

questions.text: The center for vertical gaze is________

choices.text: Rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus:

  • Rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus is the center for vertical gaze.
  • The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal (riMLF) is a part of the midbrain, specifically located in the interstitial nucleus of Cajal.
  • It is involved in the control and coordination of vertical eye movements.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Pontine Paramedian Reticular formation:

  • The Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation (PPRF) is the center for horizontal gaze..
  • The PPRF is located in the pons and coordinates the activity of the abducens nucleus and the contralateral oculomotor nucleus, facilitating horizontal gaze.

Option B. Raphe Nucleus:

  • The raphe nuclei are a group of nuclei found in the brainstem. They are involved in regulating sleep, mood, and certain autonomic functions.

Option D.

  • The substantia nigra is a critical brain region for the production of dopamine which affects many systems of the central nervous system ranging from movement control, cognitive executive functions, and emotional limbic activity

questions.text: Which one of the options below represents a site that has immunological privilege?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Seminiferous tubule:

  • Immunological privilege refers to the ability of certain anatomical sites or tissues to exhibit reduced immune surveillance and regulation. These privileged sites are characterized by the presence of specialized mechanisms that protect them from immune-mediated damage or inflammation.
  • The seminiferous tubules, which are structures found in the testes, are considered immunologically privileged sites. They play a crucial role in the production of sperm cells. The seminiferous tubules are protected from immune responses because they are enclosed within the blood-testis barrier, a specialized structure formed by tight junctions between the cells lining the tubules.

Examples of immunologically privileged sites include:

  1. Eyes (e.g., the cornea, anterior chamber)
  2. Brain (due to the blood-brain barrier)
  3. Testes (specifically the seminiferous tubules, protected by the blood-testis barrier)
  4. Ovaries
  5. Pregnant uterus (fetus in particular)

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. They are not immunologically privileged sites

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 55-year-old male patient who visited the OPD with complaints of experiencing glare while driving at night, despite having cataract surgery a year ago? The patient's best corrected visual acuity is 6/12 in the right eye and 6/9 in the left eye, with no improvement observed when using a pinhole.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Posterior capsular opacification:

  • Based on the patient's history of cataract surgery and the symptoms of glare during night drives, posterior capsular opacification is the most likely diagnosis.
  • During cataract surgery, the posterior capsule of the lens is left intact to support the intraocular lens (IOL) implant. It is caused by the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have remained within the capsular bag fol-lowing cataract extraction. . This condition is known as posterior capsular opacification (PCO) or secondary cataract or after cataract.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cystoid macular edema: Cystoid macular edema (CME) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the macula, which is the central part of the retina responsible for sharp central vision. It is characterized by blurring, especially for near tasks, and sometimes distortion.

Option B - Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy: Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy is a condition that can occur after cataract surgery, characterized by corneal edema and swelling.

Option C - ARMD (Age-Related Macular Degeneration): Age-related macular degeneration is a progressive degenerative disease affecting the macula, which leads to central vision loss. It commonly presents in individuals over the age of 50 and can cause symptoms such as blurred or distorted central vision.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Amikacin:

  • Amikacin is not commonly used for the treatment of typhoid fever in adults. Typhoid fever is a systemic bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi, and appropriate antibiotic therapy is essential for effective treatment.
  • The currently recommended drugs are as follows:
    • Third-generation cephalosporins: Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice for empirical treatment; given 1–2 g/day, IV, for 10–14 Days
    • Azithromycin: Alternative drug for empirical therapy. Given orally, 1g/day for 5 days.
    • Fluoroquinolones, e.g., ciprofloxacin: It can be given only if it is found susceptible. It is given as 500 mg twice a day orally for 5 days.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D of an explanation.

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with diarrhea and vomiting for three days. Which of the following enterotoxins is most likely responsible for the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NSP4:

  • Diarrhea and vomiting in a 6-month-old child are commonly associated with viral gastroenteritis, particularly caused by rotavirus infection. Rotavirus is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children worldwide.
  • Rotavirus produces several viral proteins, including enterotoxins, that contribute to the pathogenesis of gastroenteritis. Among these, NSP4 (Nonstructural Protein 4) is an enterotoxin primarily responsible for causing diarrhea by altering epithelial cell function and permeability.
  • Structural proteins of Rotavirus:
    • Structural protein: VP1-4, VP6, VP7.
    • Non-structural protein: NSP1-6.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - NSP6: NSP6 is another nonstructural protein produced by rotavirus. However, it is not primarily associated with causing diarrhea or vomiting in infected individuals.

Option C - VP3: VP3 is a structural protein of the rotavirus and is involved in the capping of the virus particle.

Option D - VP7: VP7 is another structural protein of the rotavirus, known as the glycoprotein, that forms the capsid layer of the virus.

questions.text: The image is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cystoid macular edema:

  • The given image depicts flower petal appearance of the retina around the macula suggestive of cystoid macular edema.
  • The leakage is always radial at macula because accumulation of fluid takes place in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers, and the outer plexiform layer at macula is radially placed and is called Henle's layer.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Flower petal pattern is characteristic of cystoid macular edema.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ocular manifestation of dengue?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cataract: 

  • "Cataract" is not an ocular manifestation typically associated with dengue fever.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Subconjunctival hemorrhage is a common ocular manifestation seen in dengue fever. It is characterized by the presence of bright red patches or spots on the white part of the eye (conjunctiva).

Option C - Uveitis: Uveitis, which refers to inflammation of the uvea, the middle layer of the eye, can occur in dengue fever. Uveitis can present with symptoms such as eye pain, redness, sensitivity to light, and blurred vision.

Option D - Retinal hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage can occur in dengue fever, particularly in severe cases or in the presence of associated complications like dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) or dengue shock syndrome (DSS).

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 65-year-old female patient with a prior diagnosis of chronic arthritis, undergoing treatment, who presents with complaints of impaired vision in both eyes and fundus angiography depicted the following finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chloroquine toxicity:

  • Chloroquine is an antimalarial medication that is sometimes used in the treatment of chronic arthritis. However, prolonged use of chloroquine can lead to retinal toxicity, specifically affecting the macula, which is responsible for central vision.
  • The characteristic findings of chloroquine toxicity include a bull's eye pattern on fundoscopy and increased fluorescence in the macular area on fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) as in the given image.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Bull’s eye maculopathy is not associated with these conditions.

questions.text: At a distance of 60 m, what is the measurement of the angle formed by the largest letter on Snellen's chart?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • The angle subtended by every alphabet on Snellen's chart is 5 minutes of arc.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. All the letters on Snellen’s chart subtend an angle of 5 minutes.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not managed using the spectacles depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C

c) Pediatric pseudophakia

  • Pediatric pseudophakia refers to the implantation of an intraocular lens (IOL) in the eye of a child who has had their natural lens removed, usually due to a cataract or other congenital eye conditions. In this case, spectacles are not used for vision correction because an IOL is implanted to replace the natural lens. Spectacles may be used for certain specific purposes like near vision, but the primary correction for vision comes from the intraocular lens.

  • Incorrect Options:

  • The spectacles shown in the image are bifocal spectacles, which contain two different types of optical power. Bifocal spectacles are commonly used for the management of :

Option A. Presbyopia: Presbyopia is an age-related condition where the natural lens of the eye loses its ability to focus on near objects due to a gradual loss of elasticity. Bifocal spectacles are often prescribed for individuals with presbyopia to correct both their distance vision and near vision. The upper part of the lens is for distance vision, while the lower part contains an additional segment called a "reading segment" for near vision.

Option B. Aphakia: Aphakia refers to the absence of the natural lens of the eye, which may occur due to surgical removal or congenital absence. In aphakic individuals, bifocal spectacles can be prescribed to address both their distance vision and near vision needs, similar to the management of presbyopia.

Option D. Hypermetropia: Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, is a refractive error that can be corrected with prescription eyeglasses to help focus light properly on the retina.

questions.text: What is the typical appearance of amniotic fluid in a full-term pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C. Clear without white specks

Explanation:

Amniotic fluid is the clear, slightly yellowish fluid that surrounds the fetus during pregnancy. In a healthy full-term pregnancy, amniotic fluid is typically clear and free of any visible particles or specks. It is odorless and serves several important functions, including protecting the fetus, maintaining a stable temperature, and allowing for fetal movement and development.

Cloudiness or the presence of white specks in amniotic fluid can indicate infection, meconium staining (when the baby passes stool in the amniotic fluid), or other complications. In such cases, further evaluation by healthcare providers is necessary to ensure the well-being of both the mother and the fetus. Clear amniotic fluid without any visible particles is a sign of a healthy amniotic sac and a healthy pregnancy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Clear with white specks : Amniotic fluid should ideally be clear without any visible specks or particles. The presence of white specks can indicate meconium staining, which occurs when the baby passes stool (meconium) in the amniotic fluid. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid may suggest fetal distress and requires medical evaluation.

Option B. Cloudy without white specks : Cloudiness in amniotic fluid can indicate infection. Cloudy amniotic fluid may contain pus or other inflammatory substances, suggesting the presence of infection in the uterus. In such cases, medical attention is necessary to assess and treat the infection.

Option D. Cloudy with white specks : This combination suggests both infection (cloudiness) and meconium staining (white specks). It indicates a potentially complicated situation that requires immediate medical intervention to assess fetal well-being and maternal health.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for the child in the image who displays enlarged corneas, sensitivity to light, and excessive tearing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • The symptoms of large corneas, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing) in the child in the picture are indicative of congenital glaucoma. Congenital glaucoma refers to a form of glaucoma that is present at birth or develops within the first few years of life. It is typically caused by abnormalities in the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B) Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a rare childhood eye cancer that affects the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. While retinoblastoma can present with various symptoms, such as leukocoria (white pupil), strabismus (misalignment of the eyes), and decreased vision, the specific symptoms mentioned in the question, such as large corneas and lacrimation, are not typical manifestations of retinoblastoma.

Option C) Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the cornea, specifically the endothelial cells responsible for maintaining corneal transparency. Symptoms of CHED usually include cloudy or hazy corneas, decreased vision, and sometimes nystagmus (involuntary eye movements). While the child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation, these symptoms are more suggestive of congenital glaucoma rather than CHED.

Option D) Megalocornea: Megalocornea is a condition characterized by abnormally large corneas. It is often inherited and can be associated with other ocular abnormalities. While megalocornea can be asymptomatic or associated with mild visual disturbances, the presence of photophobia and lacrimation in the child suggests a more likely diagnosis of congenital glaucoma, which is specifically associated with increased intraocular pressure and related symptoms.

questions.text: The following image indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Oculomotor palsy:

  • The image indicates the following findings which are suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy/third nerve palsy.
    • A - Profound ptosis due to weakness of the levator muscle.
    • B - Abduction and depression in the primary position due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
    • C - Normal abduction as the lateral rectus is intact
    • D - Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.
    • E - Limited elevation due to weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
    • F - Limited depression due to weakness of the inferior rectus.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trochlear nerve palsy: It presents with vertical diplopia and torsional diplopia with characteristic head posture to the contralateral side.

Option B - Abducens nerve palsy: It is characterized by esotropia in the affected eye with marked limitation of abduction (weakness of lateral rectus muscle) and normal adduction.

Option C - Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: It is characterized by defective ipsilateral adduction, and the contralateral abducting eye showing ataxic nystagmus.

questions.text: A lady with 7 weeks of amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. Crown Rump Length was 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks on TVS. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B.

  • In this scenario, the patient has presented with slight vaginal spotting and is at 7 weeks of amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods). The crown rump length (CRL) measured during the transvaginal ultrasound is 5 mm, and a well-formed gestational sac is observed with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks on TVS.
  • Given these findings, the next line of management would be to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week. This follow-up ultrasound is important to assess the growth and development of the embryo, particularly to confirm the presence of fetal cardiac activity. At this early stage of pregnancy, the absence of cardiac activity may indicate a nonviable pregnancy, such as a missed miscarriage or blighted ovum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Wait and watch for 4 weeks: Waiting for 4 weeks without any further assessment or intervention would not be the appropriate management in this case. It is necessary to closely monitor the pregnancy and assess for any changes in subsequent ultrasounds.

Option C. Serum HCG levels: While measuring serum human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels can provide additional information about the progression of pregnancy, it may not be the next immediate step in management. Serial HCG levels can be useful in monitoring the rise or fall of HCG levels over time, but in this case, a repeat TVS is more appropriate to evaluate the viability of the pregnancy.

Option D. Medical intervention: Medical intervention, such as medications or procedures, is not indicated as the next step in management based on the provided information. Further evaluation through repeat TVS is necessary before considering any medical interventions.

questions.text: What is the appropriate approach to managing a 76-year-old woman who has a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora measuring 2 cm x 3 cm for the past 6 months, with no palpable lymph nodes, and biopsy indicating squamous cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Total vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical local excision with U/L LAD

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Radical local excision with U/L LAD:

  • In this case, the patient presents with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora that has been persistent for 6 months. The appropriate management for this case would be a Radical local excision with U/L LAD

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Total vulvectomy with unilateral lymph node dissection: Total vulvectomy involves the complete removal of the vulva, which may not be necessary in this case, as the tumor is limited to the labia majora. Additionally, unilateral lymph node dissection would not be sufficient because the tumor could potentially spread to the contralateral side.

Option C - Simple vulvectomy: Simple vulvectomy involves the removal of the tumor along with a margin of healthy tissue, without lymph node dissection. However, in cases where there is a risk of lymph node involvement, as indicated by the size and characteristics of the tumor, lymph node dissection is necessary for accurate staging and to guide further treatment.

Option D - Chemoradiation with resection: Chemoradiation with resection may be considered as an alternative treatment approach in some cases, but it is not the primary management option for squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Surgery, such as vulvectomy, is typically the initial treatment of choice, especially if the tumor is localized and resectable.

questions.text: What advice should be given to a pregnant woman with a known heart condition who is in her first trimester and has a history of warfarin embryopathy?

choices.text: Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

questions.solution:
Correct Option B.

  • In this scenario, the pregnant female has a known cardiac disease and a history of warfarin embryopathy. Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that crosses the placenta and can cause fetal developmental abnormalities, known as warfarin embryopathy. Therefore, it is crucial to manage anticoagulation therapy appropriately during pregnancy to minimize the risk to the developing fetus.
  • The correct approach in this situation is to replace warfarin with heparin in the first trimester. Heparin is a different type of anticoagulant that does not cross the placenta and is considered safer during pregnancy. By switching to heparin, the risk of further embryopathy or developmental abnormalities associated with warfarin can be minimized.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Continue warfarin throughout the pregnancy: Continuing warfarin throughout the pregnancy is not recommended in this case, as it can pose a risk to the developing fetus and potentially lead to further embryopathy or developmental abnormalities.

Option C. Give acicoumarin: Acicoumarin is another oral anticoagulant similar to warfarin. Given the history of warfarin embryopathy, it is not advisable to substitute warfarin with acicoumarin, as it has a similar mechanism of action and potential risks to the fetus.

Option D. Use LMW heparin: Low molecular weight (LMW) heparin is a form of heparin that is commonly used for anticoagulation during pregnancy. However, in this specific case of a known history of warfarin embryopathy, using standard heparin (unfractionated heparin) is preferred over LMW heparin, as it allows for more precise dosage adjustments and monitoring.

questions.text: What is the crucial indicator of male fertility in a semen analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Morphology:

  • Morphology refers to the shape and structure of sperm cells. It is assessed by examining sperm under a microscope and determining the percentage of sperm cells that have normal morphology. Normal sperm morphology is crucial for successful fertilization, as it affects the sperm's ability to penetrate and fertilize the egg.

Incorrect Options:

OptionB. Concentration: Concentration refers to the number of sperm cells present in a given volume of semen. While sperm concentration is an important parameter in semen analysis, it alone does not provide a comprehensive assessment of male fertility.

Option C. Motility: Motility refers to the sperm's ability to move and swim forward. It is an important parameter in semen analysis as it indicates the sperm's ability to reach and penetrate the egg for fertilization.

Option D. Sperm Count: Sperm count refers to the total number of sperm cells in the ejaculate. The quality of sperm, including factors like morphology and motility, is equally important for successful fertilization.

questions.text: Based on the provided semen analysis results, what would be the diagnosis for a young male? The concentration is 5 million per milliliter, motility is 50%, and normal morphology is 4%.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Oligospermia:

  • In the given semen analysis results, the parameters are as follows:
    • Concentration: 5 million/ml (sperm cells per milliliter of semen)
    • Motility: 50% (percentage of sperm cells showing forward movement)
    • Normal Morphology: 4% (percentage of sperm cells with normal shape and structure)
  • Based on these results, the diagnosis is Oligospermia, which refers to a low sperm concentration. In general, a sperm concentration below 15 million/ml is considered low. In this case, the concentration of 5 million/ml falls below the normal range, indicating oligospermia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Teratozoospermia: Teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology, where a high percentage of sperm cells have abnormal shape or structure. In the given scenario, the normal morphology is 4%, which is within the normal range. Therefore, teratozoospermia is not the correct diagnosis.

Option C. Asthenozoospermia: Asthenozoospermia refers to reduced sperm motility, where a low percentage of sperm cells show forward movement. In the given scenario, the motility is 50%, which is within the normal range. Therefore, asthenozoospermia is not the correct diagnosis.

OptionD. Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT) is a combination of low sperm concentration, reduced sperm motility, and abnormal sperm morphology. While the given semen analysis results indicate low sperm concentration (oligospermia), the motility and morphology are within the normal range. Therefore, oligoasthenoteratozoospermia is not the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: In the context of a woman who is 31 weeks pregnant and experiencing lower abdominal pain, the clinician is worried about the possibility of preterm labor. Which test would be the most suitable in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

  • In the scenario of a woman with 31 weeks of gestation presenting with lower abdominal pain and concern for preterm labor, the most appropriate test is fetal fibronectin (fFN).
  • Fetal fibronectin (fFN): Fetal fibronectin is a protein that acts as a biological glue between the fetal sac and the uterine lining. It helps to maintain the stability of the fetal sac in the uterus. The presence of fFN in vaginal secretions between 22 and 35 weeks of gestation may indicate a higher risk of preterm labor. Therefore, testing for fFN can help assess the likelihood of preterm labor in this scenario and guide further management.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP): AFP is a protein produced by the fetal liver. It is primarily used as a screening test for neural tube defects and certain fetal abnormalities, but it is not specifically used for assessing preterm labor. Therefore, AFP is not the most appropriate test in this scenario.

Option B. Beta HCG (β-hCG): Beta HCG is a hormone produced by the placenta. It is commonly measured in pregnancy tests and is not specific to preterm labor. Therefore, β-hCG is not the most appropriate test in this scenario.

Option D. PAPP-A (pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A): PAPP-A is a protein produced by the placenta. It is commonly measured as a part of first-trimester screening for chromosomal abnormalities. It is not specific to preterm labor and therefore not the most appropriate test in this scenario.

questions.text: What is the appropriate course of action for the management of a woman who has had two prior pregnancies, no live births, and has missed her menstrual period for 9 weeks? She underwent a conization procedure one year ago and has been regularly monitored, with no signs of abnormality on her recent PAP smear. Additionally, she experienced preterm labor at 30 and 32 weeks during her previous pregnancies.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A.

  • USG to see cervical length: In this scenario, the patient has a history of conization, which involves the removal of a portion of the cervix. Conization can weaken the cervix and increase the risk of cervical insufficiency, leading to preterm labor and delivery. Assessing the cervical length via ultrasound helps determine if there is cervical shortening or insufficient cervical length, which would necessitate interventions such as cervical cerclage (suturing the cervix) to prevent preterm delivery.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Cervical cerclage: Cervical cerclage is a surgical procedure in which the cervix is stitched closed to provide support and prevent premature dilation. While cervical cerclage is a potential intervention for patients with cervical insufficiency, it is not the next step in management. First, the cervical length needs to be evaluated via ultrasound to determine if cervical insufficiency is present.

Option C. Complete bed rest: Complete bed rest has been traditionally recommended in the past for patients with a history of preterm labor or cervical insufficiency. However, current evidence does not support the routine use of bed rest as an effective intervention for preventing preterm birth. Therefore, complete bed rest is not the next step in management.

Option D. Abdominal cerclage: Abdominal cerclage is a surgical procedure in which a band or suture is placed around the top of the cervix through an abdominal incision. It is usually reserved for cases of recurrent or severe cervical insufficiency. However, it is not the next step in management for this patient. Initially, the cervical length needs to be assessed via ultrasound.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent action when a patient, who has been taking MALA-N for the past 6 months and has been adhering to the medication, reports having missed periods?

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period

questions.solution:
Correct Option C-Beta HCG estimation:

  • When a patient on a contraceptive method such as MALA-N (which contains a combination of levonorgestrel and ethinyl estradiol) complains of missed periods, it is important to rule out pregnancy as the cause. The next step in this scenario would be to perform a beta HCG estimation.
  • Beta HCG estimation is a reliable test for determining pregnancy. By performing this test, pregnancy can be confirmed or ruled out as the cause of the missed periods in the patient on MALA-N.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: While a transvaginal ultrasound can provide additional information about the reproductive organs, it may not be the most appropriate initial step when a patient on contraception reports missed periods.

Option B. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While it is true that hormonal contraceptives can sometimes cause changes in menstrual bleeding patterns, including missed periods or lighter flow, it is essential to ensure that pregnancy is not the underlying cause.

Option D. Serum FSH and LH: Measurement of serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) levels may be useful in assessing ovarian function and potential hormonal imbalances.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient came with a flexion contracture of the hip. Which of the following test is useful in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thomas test

 

Explanation:

 

Thomas test:

  • The Thomas test is specifically designed to detect hip flexion contracture.

  • The patient lies supine, and one hip is maximally flexed to flatten the lumbar spine and stabilize the pelvis. If the opposite leg lifts off the table (instead of staying flat), it indicates a flexion contracture of the contralateral hip.

  • It is commonly used in elderly patients or individuals with hip arthritis or postural abnormalities.

Thomas test is the most appropriate and specific clinical test to diagnose hip flexion contracture.

Allen’s test (Option A):

  • Is used to assess arterial blood flow to the hand, especially the patency of the radial and ulnar arteries before arterial blood gas sampling or cannulation.

  • Not related to hip joint pathology.

Trendelenburg test (Option B):

  • Assesses the integrity of the hip abductor muscles, particularly the gluteus medius and minimus.

  • A positive test indicates weakness or instability in these muscles (e.g., due to superior gluteal nerve injury), not a flexion contracture.

Ober test (Option D):

  • Used to detect iliotibial band (IT band) tightness or contracture.

  • The patient lies on the unaffected side, and the examiner extends and abducts the affected leg, then allows it to drop. If it remains elevated, it suggests IT band tightness.

  • Not specific for hip flexion contracture.

questions.text: Against which serotypes is the HPV nonavalent vaccine effective?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D.

  • This is the correct answer. It includes all the serotypes covered by the HPV nonavalent vaccine, which are serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58. These serotypes are associated with a high risk of developing HPV-related diseases, including cervical cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These are incorrect options

questions.text: Which of the following interventions is not a part of the active management of the third stage of labor aimed at preventing postpartum hemorrhage?

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.solution:
• Active management of the third stage of labor refers to a set of interventions performed immediately after the birth of the baby to reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage (excessive bleeding after childbirth). The goal of active management is to promote the prompt and effective expulsion of the placenta, reduce uterine atony (lack of uterine contraction), and prevent excessive bleeding.

Correct Option B.

  • Delayed clamping, cutting, and ligation of cord - This option is not a part of the active management of the third stage of labor. Delayed cord clamping is a separate practice that involves waiting for a short period (usually at least 30 seconds to 1 minute) before clamping and cutting the umbilical cord after the baby is born. It has benefits for the newborn but is not directly related to preventing postpartum hemorrhage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Uterotonic within 1 minute of delivery - This is a key component of active management. Administration of a uterotonic medication (such as oxytocin) within 1 minute of delivery helps to promote uterine contractions, which aids in the expulsion of the placenta and reduces the risk of postpartum hemorrhage.

Option C. Gentle massage of the uterus - Gentle uterine massage is a part of active management. It is typically performed after the placenta is delivered to help the uterus contract and prevent excessive bleeding.

Option D. Controlled cord traction - Controlled cord traction is a component of active management. It involves applying gentle traction on the umbilical cord while simultaneously supporting the uterus to help facilitate the delivery of the placenta.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man involved in a fight injured his finger and presented with the deformity as shown in the following image. His X-ray is normal. The most appropriate management of the given condition at this stage is:

choices.text: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Splint the finger in hyperextension:

Mallet Finger:

  • Also called baseball finger or drop finger.
  • Results from injury to the extensor tendon of the terminal phalanx.

Treatment:

  • An acute mallet finger should be splinted with a Mallet Finger splint for 8 weeks - Best management.
  • Smilies cast - outdated treatment.
  • Surgery is not advised even if there is fracture-dislocation.
  • Fowler's central slip tenotomy:
    • Plastic surgery for old and neglected Mallet fingers.
    • Done for old lesions interfering with hand functions.

  • Splinting the finger in hyperextension is a common approach for managing certain types of finger injuries, particularly those involving extensor tendon injuries. This technique helps to keep the finger in an extended position, preventing flexion contractures and promoting healing of the extensor tendon.
  • It's important to note that a normal X-ray does not exclude the possibility of soft tissue injuries, such as tendon or ligament damage. If the clinical examination suggests a potential flexor or extensor tendon injury, appropriate management should be initiated, even if the X-ray appears normal

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Splint the finger in flexion: Splinting the finger in flexion is typically indicated for injuries involving the flexor tendon or flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) avulsion. This type of injury often presents with the inability to actively flex the finger. However, based on the information provided, it is mentioned that the X-ray is normal, which suggests that there is no evident bony injury. If there is no specific indication of a flexor tendon injury, splinting the finger in flexion may not be the most appropriate choice.

Option B - Buddy strapping: Buddy strapping involves taping or bandaging an injured finger to an adjacent finger for support and stability. It is commonly used for minor finger sprains or simple fractures, especially when there is no significant displacement or rotation. However, in the case of a finger deformity resulting from a fight-related injury, buddy strapping alone may not provide adequate stability or address potential ligament or tendon injuries. It is essential to assess the specific nature and extent of the injury before determining the appropriate management.

Option C - Surgical repair of the flexor tendon: The option of surgical repair of the flexor tendon may be considered if there is a confirmed flexor tendon injury or if conservative management fails. However, based on the information provided, a normal X-ray suggests that there is no evident bony injury or obvious indication for surgical intervention at this stage. Surgical repair of the flexor tendon is typically reserved for cases where there is a complete tendon laceration, significant tendon retraction, or inability to actively flex the finger.

questions.text: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except?

choices.text: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.solution:
Option D. Suburethral nodule.

A suburethral nodule is not a typical sign of choriocarcinoma. Choriocarcinoma primarily affects the uterus and may metastasize to other organs, but it does not commonly present as a suburethral nodule.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Increased number of theca lutein cysts : Choriocarcinoma can cause the development of theca lutein cysts in the ovaries due to overstimulation by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). These cysts are large and can often be identified on imaging studies.

Option B. Persistently enlarged uterus : Choriocarcinoma can lead to a persistently enlarged uterus due to the abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue. This is one of the common signs of choriocarcinoma.

Option C. Plateau of high serum hCG : Serum hCG levels are elevated in choriocarcinoma. However, instead of fluctuating levels, choriocarcinoma often presents with a plateau of high serum hCG, indicating persistent elevation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the scar tissue in patellar clunk syndrome?

choices.text: Superior pole of the patella, impinging during flexion
Superior pole of the patella, impinging during extension
Inferior pole of the patella, impinging during flexion
Inferior pole of the patella, impinging during extension

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Superior pole of the patella, impinging during extension

  • Patellar clunk syndrome (PCS) is attributed to the formation of a fibrous nodule at the junction of the proximal (superior) patellar pole and the articular aspect of the quadriceps tendon. This nodule becomes entrapped in the intercondylar box of the femoral component during knee flexion. Upon knee extension to 30-45 degrees, the nodule suddenly dislodges, resulting in a painful audible clunk

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect and the correct option is explained above.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Intermittent Pneumatic Compression (IPC) devices, often employed in medical settings to mitigate the chances of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and enhance circulation in high-risk patients?

choices.text: They deliver a continuous flow of pressurized air to the lower extremities.
They apply periodic pressure and release cycles to the legs using inflatable cuffs.
They administer medication through subcutaneous injections to prevent blood clot formation.
They use heat therapy to improve blood flow and prevent clot formation.

questions.solution:
The correct option is 2. They apply periodic pressure and release cycles to the legs using inflatable cuffs.

Explanation of Options:

  1. They deliver a continuous flow of pressurized air to the lower extremities: This option is not accurate. Intermittent Pneumatic Compression (IPC) devices do not deliver a continuous flow of air. Instead, they work by applying periodic pressure and release cycles to the legs through inflatable cuffs.

  2. They apply periodic pressure and release cycles to the legs using inflatable cuffs: This is the correct answer. IPC devices consist of inflatable cuffs that are placed around the legs. These cuffs inflate and deflate in a cyclical manner to help mimic the natural pumping action of the calf muscles. This helps improve venous blood flow, prevent stasis, and reduce the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

  3. They administer medication through subcutaneous injections to prevent blood clot formation: This option is not accurate. IPC devices do not administer medication. They work solely by applying mechanical pressure to aid in improving blood circulation and preventing blood clot formation.

  4. They use heat therapy to improve blood flow and prevent clot formation: This option is not accurate. While heat therapy can help improve blood flow, IPC devices primarily work through mechanical pressure and the cyclic inflation and deflation of cuffs, which aids in enhancing venous return and reducing the risk of DVT.

questions.text: What is the earliest indication of acute compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • The earliest symptom of acute compartment syndrome is pain.
  • Acute compartment syndrome is a serious condition that occurs when pressure within a muscle compartment increases to a level that restricts blood flow and causes tissue damage. It most commonly affects the limbs, especially the lower leg.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Pallor: Pallor, or paleness of the skin, can occur in advanced stages of compartment syndrome when the blood flow to the affected muscles and tissues is severely compromised. However, pallor is not an early symptom and may not be present in the initial stages.

Option C. Paresthesia: Paresthesia refers to abnormal sensations, such as tingling or numbness. It can occur as the condition progresses and nerve function becomes compromised. Similar to pallor, paresthesia is not an early symptom and may develop in later stages.

Option D. Paralysis: Paralysis, or loss of muscle function, is a late sign of compartment syndrome and is typically indicative of severe tissue damage and nerve involvement. It is not an early symptom.

questions.text: What is the most suitable treatment for a 55-year-old female diagnosed with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium accompanied by atypia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Simple Hysterectomy:

  • Simple hysterectomy: Simple hysterectomy, which involves the removal of the uterus, is considered the ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia. This approach removes the entire uterus, including the atypical cells, eliminating the risk of further progression to endometrial cancer. It is particularly recommended for women who have completed their childbearing and do not desire future fertility.
  • Simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia is a precancerous condition characterized by abnormal cell growth in the endometrial lining of the uterus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: Medroxyprogesterone acetate, a progestin hormone, can be used as a conservative treatment option for women who wish to preserve their uterus and fertility. However, in the case of atypical hyperplasia, the risk of underlying cancerous changes is higher, and conservative treatment may not be sufficient to eliminate the risk completely.

Option C. Levonorgestrel: Levonorgestrel, another progestin hormone, can also be used as a conservative treatment option for simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia. However, as mentioned before, the risk of underlying cancerous changes warrants more definitive treatment options.

Option D. Radiotherapy: It is reserved for cases where the disease has progressed to endometrial cancer or if there is a high risk of recurrence after other treatments.

questions.text: Which tumor does not cause osteomalacia and phosphaturia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Breast Carcinoma:

  • Breast carcinoma, or breast cancer, is a malignant tumor that originates in the breast tissue. Unlike the other options, breast carcinoma is not commonly associated with osteomalacia and phosphaturia. Breast carcinoma primarily affects the breast tissue and can metastasize to bones, causing bone-related complications such as bone pain or fractures. However, it does not typically produce FGF23 or directly leads to tumor-induced osteomalacia and phosphaturia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that primarily affects the osteoblasts, which are the cells responsible for forming new bone tissue. While osteosarcoma itself does not directly cause osteomalacia and phosphaturia, there have been rare cases where osteosarcoma has been associated with tumor-induced osteomalacia. In these rare cases, the tumor can produce excessive levels of fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23), leading to the development of osteomalacia and phosphaturia.

Option B - Hemangiopericytoma: Hemangiopericytoma is a rare type of tumor that arises from the pericytes, which are specialized cells found around blood vessels. Similar to osteosarcoma, hemangiopericytoma itself does not commonly cause osteomalacia and phosphaturia. However, there have been reported cases where hemangiopericytoma has been associated with tumor-induced osteomalacia. The tumor can produce elevated levels of FGF23, leading to the development of osteomalacia and phosphaturia.

Option C - Fibrosarcoma: Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumor that originates from fibrous connective tissue. Like osteosarcoma and hemangiopericytoma, fibrosarcoma itself does not typically cause osteomalacia and phosphaturia. However, there have been rare cases where fibrosarcoma has been associated with tumor-induced osteomalacia. The tumor can produce excessive FGF23, resulting in the development of osteomalacia and phosphaturia.

questions.text: What is the best test to diagnose a vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Cystoscopy:

  • Cystoscopy is a diagnostic procedure that allows direct visualization of the inside of the bladder, urethra, and sometimes the ureters. In the case of a vesicovaginal fistula, cystoscopy is the best diagnostic test.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. 3 swab test: The 3 swab test can also be used to diagnose a vesicovaginal fistula but a cystoscopy is the best test.

Option C. MRI: It is not typically considered the primary diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula. In certain cases, MRI may be used to evaluate complex or recurrent fistulas or to assess the surrounding structures.

Option D. Cystometry: It helps evaluate bladder function and assess urinary symptoms. While cystometry can provide information about bladder function, it is not specifically used to diagnose or assess vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text: What is the most common form of arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Osteoarthritis:

  • Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of arthritis. It is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown and gradual loss of cartilage in the joints. Osteoarthritis primarily affects weight-bearing joints such as the knees, hips, and spine, as well as the hands and other joints. It is associated with joint pain, stiffness, swelling, and reduced range of motion. Osteoarthritis is typically age-related and can be influenced by factors such as joint overuse, joint trauma, obesity, and genetics.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rheumatoid Arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disease in which the immune system mistakenly attacks the synovium (the lining of the joints). It causes chronic inflammation, leading to joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and potentially joint deformities. Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by the symmetrical involvement of multiple joints, typically affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. It is more common in women than men and can also affect other organs in the body. While rheumatoid arthritis is a significant form of arthritis, it is not as prevalent as osteoarthritis.

Option B - Psoriatic Arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that occurs in some individuals with psoriasis, a chronic skin condition characterized by red, scaly patches on the skin. Psoriatic arthritis can cause joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and tenderness. It typically affects the joints of the fingers and toes but can also involve larger joints such as the knees, hips, and spine. Psoriatic arthritis is less common than osteoarthritis, but its association with psoriasis makes it an important consideration in patients with both skin and joint symptoms.

Option C - Seronegative Arthritis: Seronegative arthritis is a term used to describe a group of inflammatory arthritis conditions that do not show certain specific antibodies, such as rheumatoid factor or anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, in the blood. Some examples of seronegative arthritis conditions include ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis. These conditions share common features of inflammatory joint involvement, but they may also have extra-articular manifestations. While seronegative arthritis conditions can cause significant joint inflammation, they are less prevalent than osteoarthritis.

questions.text: What is the recommended duration for isolating a child after diagnosis of bacterial meningitis in order to prevent further transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics:

  • After starting antibiotics for bacterial meningitis, the child should be isolated for at least 24 hours.
  • This allows sufficient time for the antibiotics to take effect, reducing the bacterial load and decreasing the risk of transmission to others.
  • After this period, the child is generally considered to be less contagious.

Incorrect Options: 

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: At what gestational age should a pregnant woman with well-controlled blood glucose levels on insulin be delivered if she has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-39 weeks:

  • Delivery at 39 weeks is the appropriate gestational age for women with well-controlled GDM. It allows for adequate fetal maturity while minimizing the risks associated with prolonged pregnancy.
  • At 39 weeks, the benefits of delivery outweigh the risks of continuing the pregnancy, considering the potential for macrosomia (large birth weight) and associated birth complications in infants of mothers with GDM.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. 37 weeks: Delivery at 37 weeks is not the standard recommendation for women with well-controlled GDM. Early delivery at 37 weeks may be considered in cases of poorly controlled GDM or if there are other medical indications such as fetal growth restriction, preeclampsia, or concerns for fetal well-being.

Option C. 38 weeks: Delivery at 38 weeks may be considered in certain cases, but 39 weeks is the preferred gestational age for delivery in women with well-controlled GDM.

Option D. 40 weeks: Delivery at 40 weeks is not the standard recommendation for women with GDM. Prolonging the pregnancy beyond 39 weeks may increase the risk of complications such as macrosomia, shoulder dystocia, and cesarean delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypoglycemia:

  • Hypoglycemia, which refers to low blood sugar levels, is not a known side effect of salbutamol. Salbutamol is primarily used as a bronchodilator to relieve symptoms of asthma and other respiratory conditions. It works by relaxing the smooth muscles in the airways, which helps improve breathing. While salbutamol can affect glucose metabolism, it typically does not cause significant changes in blood sugar levels.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hypokalemia:  Hypokalemia refers to low levels of potassium in the blood. Salbutamol is a beta-2 adrenergic agonist, and its use can lead to an intracellular shift of potassium, potentially causing transient hypokalemia. This occurs due to the stimulation of beta-2 adrenergic receptors, which can activate the sodium-potassium pump and cause the movement of potassium into cells. However, significant hypokalemia is more commonly associated with higher doses or prolonged use of salbutamol. It can also be used to treat hyperkalemia.

Option C - Tremors: Tremors, or involuntary shaking of the hands, is a known side effect of salbutamol. It is a result of the drug's stimulation of beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the muscles. While tremors can be bothersome, they are generally temporary and resolve once the drug is metabolized and cleared from the body.

Option D - Tachycardia: Tachycardia, which refers to a rapid heart rate, is a common side effect of salbutamol. Salbutamol stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the heart, leading to an increased heart rate. This effect is desired in the context of bronchodilation but can be a concern in individuals with pre-existing heart conditions. It is important to monitor heart rate during salbutamol use, especially in individuals with cardiovascular issues.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent heart sounds would be considered within the normal range during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A.

  • The presence of an S3 heart sound can be considered normal during pregnancy. An S3 is a low-frequency sound heard during early diastole and is caused by rapid ventricular filling. In pregnancy, the increased blood volume and elevated cardiac output can lead to increased ventricular filling, resulting in the presence of an S3 sound.
  • During pregnancy, certain physiological changes occur in the cardiovascular system to accommodate the increased demands of the growing fetus. These changes can affect heart sounds.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. S4: The presence of an S4 heart sound is not considered a normal finding in pregnancy. An S4 is an additional heart sound heard during late diastole and is associated with decreased ventricular compliance. It is more commonly observed in conditions such as hypertensive heart disease or ventricular hypertrophy, which may not be typical in a healthy pregnancy.

Option C. Fixed splitting of S2: Fixed splitting of S2 refers to a constant delay in the closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves, resulting in a fixed interval between the two components of the second heart sound. This finding is not typically associated with normal pregnancy and may indicate underlying cardiac abnormalities.

Option D. Pericardial knock: A pericardial knock refers to an early diastolic sound caused by abrupt cessation of ventricular filling due to restrictive pericarditis. This is not a normal finding in pregnancy and suggests an abnormal condition affecting the pericardium.

questions.text: Which of the following medications must only be dispensed with a prescription from a licensed medical practitioner?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B. Schedule H drugs

  • Schedule H drugs are drugs that are required to be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner. These drugs have a higher potential for misuse or abuse and may pose risks if used without proper medical supervision. Examples of Schedule H drugs include antibiotics, opioids, sedatives, and certain other prescription medications.

Incorrect Options 

Option A. Schedule M drugs: Schedule M refers to drugs that are manufactured and marketed in India. These drugs are required to comply with Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) guidelines. Schedule M does not specifically regulate the sale or prescription requirements of these drugs. However, it is important to note that the sale of all drugs, including Schedule M drugs, should comply with the applicable drug regulations and requirements, which may include prescription-only status for certain medications.

Option C. Schedule J drugs: Schedule J refers to a category of drugs known as "Strengthening Schedule J Drugs." These drugs are considered essential medicines for public health and are used to treat various diseases and conditions. The sale and prescription requirements for Schedule J drugs may vary depending on the specific drug and its formulation. Some Schedule J drugs may be available over-the-counter (OTC) or sold with certain restrictions, while others may require a prescription.

Option D. Schedule X drugs: Schedule X drugs are a category of drugs that have a high potential for abuse and addiction. These drugs are tightly regulated and are subject to strict prescription and dispensing requirements. Schedule X drugs include narcotics, psychotropic substances, and certain other drugs that are considered dangerous and are controlled under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act, of 1985. These drugs can only be prescribed and dispensed by registered medical practitioners with specific licenses.

questions.text: The loading dose of a drug is governed primarily by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Volume of distribution:

  • The volume of distribution (Vd) is a pharmacokinetic parameter that represents the apparent space in the body available to contain the drug. It is a theoretical volume that indicates how extensively a drug is distributed throughout the body relative to its concentration in the plasma. A higher volume of distribution suggests that the drug is extensively distributed in the tissues, while a lower volume of distribution indicates more confinement to the plasma. The volume of distribution influences the loading dose of a drug, as it helps determine the initial dose required to achieve a desired concentration in the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Clearance: Clearance refers to the rate at which a drug is eliminated from the body. It is a pharmacokinetic parameter that measures how efficiently the body removes a drug from the systemic circulation. Clearance is influenced by various factors, including liver function, kidney function, and metabolic processes. A higher clearance indicates faster elimination of the drug from the body, while a lower clearance means slower elimination. Clearance plays a role in determining the dosing frequency and adjustment of a drug.

Option C - Plasma half-life: The plasma half-life is the time it takes for the concentration of a drug in the plasma to decrease by half. It is a pharmacokinetic parameter that reflects the rate of elimination of the drug from the systemic circulation. The half-life is influenced by factors such as clearance, metabolism, and excretion. A longer half-life means the drug remains in the body for a longer duration, while a shorter half-life indicates faster elimination. The plasma half-life is used to determine the dosing interval for a drug, as it indicates how frequently the drug needs to be administered to maintain a therapeutic concentration.

Option D - Bioavailability: Bioavailability is the fraction or percentage of an administered drug that reaches systemic circulation in an unchanged form.
